text:
The was a reason why this BK was practically empty when I stopped in for a quick breakfast the other day.  

The Biscuit for my sandwich was hard and too small to enclose its contents.  It appeared to be a tube biscuit that had been made earlier and left in the open air to dry out, and then microwaved just before sale.  It rehardened quickly and was a crumbly mess to eat.  Just not very good, despite the fact that the rest of the ingredients seemed fresh.  

Given the competition across the street, it is difficult to see how this place survives. Maybe their burgers are better, but I won't be back to find out.

It pains me to remember the recently completed dinner at Taco Suave.  Such high expectations after reading the other reviews.  Such auspicious beginnings. Such a sudden and disappointing finale.

We walked in to this tiny strip mall corner restaurant. About a dozen tables with white table clothes.  I was thinking that in my experience, the hole in the wall Mexican joints were always the best.  At least, that had been true in Arizona, New Mexico, Colorado and even SoCal. 

 We sat and ordered the Agua de Pina (Pineapple Water), which was a first and a pleasant drink of diluted pineapple juice whipped to a froth.  Really good! I was getting more excited as I imagined we had just discovered the Fountain of Youth drink right here in Warrington.  Then the homemade Chips and Fresh Salsa came out. Heavy crunchy mild oily sensation with a mild Mexi flavor, and a Tomato, Cilantro Salsa with a sweetness equal to the chili's heat.  Loved it. 

Encouraged and feeling adventurous by the fun of the apps and drink, I went for the Pollo Dorado (Golden Fried Chicken), the most expensive item on the menu.  Visions of plump chicken breast with a wonderful fruity sauce danced in my head. My friends had a Burrito de Carne Asada, and a Taco con Queso.  

What was placed before me was instead three over cooked deep fried drumsticks with an oil soaked brown coating that tasted primarily of salt.  My physical reaction to eating this was matched by the instantly deflated sense of gluttony so rudely assaulted and kicked to the curb.  I kept eating hoping for a secondary burst of flavor to save this.  It did not come. I passed around the chicken and the reaction was universal. Bad. 

The Burrito de Carne Asada was large and full of bits of beef and cheese, but way too mild, and a bit too fatty.  It was left one third eaten.  The Taco con Queso presented well, but was practically tasteless.  We liberally added hot salsa to throw them life preservers, but we could not save them.  The dinner was a victim of drowning. 

We will not be back.  I wish I had a different review to write about Taco Suave, but true to the Yelpers Creed, I cannot hide from the bitter taste of a disappointing meal.  

Our server, Mirna, was great!

The Blue Duck is a nice place to stop for brunch or lunch if you find yourself in the vicinity.  It has a reputation for offering "Center City" atmosphere, with "Northeast Philly" earthiness.  I guess that means you don't always have to run downtown to find a cool place to eat, or conversely, that Northeast Philly now has its own duck fat fries outlet.  Can I hear a, "Hallelujah!"?

We stopped in for a late lunch after an appointment with Homeland Security on Drummond Road nearby.  That is never a sparkling experience, and we all wanted something to wash away the bureaucratic dust that comes with dealing with the Feds. We ordered three of their signature burgers, and the Salt & Pepper Fries for the table.  Water all around. We waited about 20 minutes for our meals to arrive, all the while smelling the grilling beef in the open kitchen.  This was a very hot day, and the HVAC was struggling to maintain the right comfort level.  Even with the front door closed, the humidity in the house was noticeable.  

The House Grind Burger, Pork Roll Burger and Beast of Northeast Burger arrived in the arms of our erstwhile server.  All looked great with Brioche-style rolls, and the individual toppings.  My Beast was a mix of Wild Boar and Beef, Smoked Gouda, Sweet Tomato Jam, Bacon and Crisp Sriracha Shoestring Onions.  Beautiful to behold.  First bite should have been awesome, but aside from the interesting flavor of the fixings, the "Medium" finish requested was in fact, "Well Done."  With the juice gone, I could not taste the difference in the meats, and found the burger less than hoped. The same was true for the House Grind, although for some reason the Pork Roll Burger came out "Medium Rare,"  and amply juiced.  The S & P Fries were good; hot, but not crisp. 

It is always awkward to low rank a popular restaurant, but it was what it was.  Someone needs to pay more attention at the grill, as it is likely to have happened before.  

Good luck with your new Center City enterprise.

I am about to give up on Frozen Yogurt joints. 

Over the last year or more, I have not found a single one that offers a quality product that tastes as good as the equivalent ice cream.  While it is nice to save on calories (if that is really the case), tasteless extrusions just don't satisfy my need for something cold, creamy and sweet.  

This Redberry, while small and clean, offers nothing better than the others.  The Traditional Vanilla and Peanut Butter choices were indistinguishable from each other.  Only the add ons had any taste. 

What's the point?

For a place that specializes in one thing - salad - there is a disconnect between their mission and final product. 

 I have eaten here a few times over the years, and while nothing I have ordered/eaten has been bad, my impression was that the bowls were thrown together by rote with excessive inattention to detail.  Often the ingredients are just dropped into the salad bowl and left unmixed or given a perfunctory stir.  Separate piles of cheese, nuts, dried fruits, etc., left where they fall.  Sometimes, one of the elements is forgotten without awareness of the shortcoming.  

When the pleasure of this experience comes in over $10 for lunch, it is difficult to think that value has been attained.  Asking for the dressing on the side to take charge of the finish is helpful, but when it becomes necessary to insure that I am dealing with a salad and not piles of vegetables as yet unrelated to each other, I feel like I am doing their jobs. 

With so many other restaurants offering healthy creative fresh salads as part of a broader menu, there seems little reason to go to a place whose sole reason for existence is doing something that is ultimately inferior to the competition.  There is something inherently contradictory in a mass produced "custom made" salad.  

That contradiction is manifest by what comes across the counter at Saladworks.

BREAKFAST TAKE OUT REVIEW

We had an office meeting in Norristown, PA, this morning. Our office manager took our requests for breakfast and ordered everything from nearby Pauline's Deli. There were eight of us.  I asked for a sausage, egg and cheese sandwich on toasted English muffin. 

When I arrived I sat at the conference table with an aluminum foil wrapped package before me. It was still warm. Upon opening, I quickly realized that I had a pork roll, egg and cheese on English, not what I had requested. This may not have been Pauline's doing, as I looked around and noticed my associate had a very similar sandwich, but with sausage. It was too late to make the exchange, as he was already happily half way through MY SANDWICH. For the sake of team building, I said nothing.

I am not a pork roll guy. Don't care for the taste, nor the texture. Still, I suffered through it, and drowned my disappointment in the hot coffee made in our office. 

Better labeling might solve this kind of mix up, and a closer examination by the consumer would certainly be a benefit. I realize that it may not be fair to say Pauline messed this up, but I really didn't care for the sandwich. Hopefully, I'll get another chance at the next breakfast session, and be able to judge what I actually wanted. 

YELP Suggestion - There should be a box to check for take out reviews. It isn't close to equivalent to evaluate a dining in experience with a take away bite. I quickly stop reading take out reviews as being irrelevant to the quality and enjoyability of the exact same meal eaten in these two divergent circumstances.

As McDonald's go, this one on West Trenton Avenue in Morrisville, Pa., is in the format of a modern smaller footprint, with a drive through that wraps tightly around the building, forcing pedestrians to cross this lane of traffic. With all the young people who frequent these kid magnets, you would think they could find a safer design.  Alas, not. 

I stopped in the other morning when traffic heading over the Delaware was so bad I decided to find a rest stop to wait for the clogged artery that is the Calhoun Street Bridge to pass its blockage.  Mickey's was right there, so I went in.  The place was clean and a little busy. Still, my order was taken promptly.  I had to wait a while for it to be filled as the staff seemed to lack any real organization for the counter.  The six people I saw all had their backs turned to the customers, and when any one of them was free and looked around to see us there, they carried out the next step in the process.  Three different people worked on my order.  I finally realized that what I was observing was the result of the heavy drive thru business which kept everyone's attention, and left those of us inside as forgotten players in their fast food game.  Efficient, perhaps, but not given to warm face to face. 

My Sausage, Egg and Cheese Biscuit was smallish, and thrown together in such a way the top of the biscuit adhered to the cheese to one side of the sandwich, leaving the rest exposed.  It was wrapped and bagged that way, and made the eating a bit awkward. I guess if this product had gone to a drive away customer, by the time it was opened, they would be too far away to do anything but grumble.  Another casualty to the dominance of drive thru culture. 

For me, I was just disappointed with the lack of care in the work product, and knew that I wasn't coming back for another round of being ignored.  

Oh. The coffee was good.

Not sure the last time RJ's boiled and baked the bagels in the bins, but as I am eating one less than 30 minutes after purchase @ 1:00 pm on a Sunday, it is already approaching staleness. Too flat upon observation; a tough slice with a sharp serrated knife; tough crust with no crispness; and too dense at its heart.  
Very ordinary. 
Bagel Train is far superior to my taste.

Great Shanghai Chinese Restaurant in the Morrisville Plaza Shopping Center is another primarily take out shop that has been around for many years providing Chinese/American dishes to the neighborhood at affordable prices.  Although there are two tables in the house, the lack of heat in winter makes it obvious they don't expect (want) people to consume their products there.  So, when I ordered sesame chicken and hot/sour soup and indicated I would eat while the food was at its peak heat, they asked me twice if they understood me correctly.

They did, and pulled out a plastic orange tray to deliver the take away containers to me, along with cheap utensils.  They were kind enough to remove the staples used to close the styro lid, so that I could gain prompt access.  

My lunch was pretty much okay.  

The hot & sour soup was made without MSG, and had a good taste with ample tofu and veggies, and the right amount of vinegar.  The sesame chicken was not over breaded, and the meat could be tasted, and was not lost in the goop.  The quantity was plenty for a midday meal.  The fried rice had been made earlier, had the tint of the bouillon it had been cooked in, and had a fairly fresh texture of being prepared earlier in the day, not yesterday.  

Overall, it was what was expected from this type of kitchen, and perhaps, slightly above average based on the soup and rice.  

The price/quality ratio was just about right, but having to wear a coat while eating is inhospitable, and knocks it down from average to just below.

This Dunkin Donuts on Bustleton Avenue in the far Northeast Philadelphia, is about average for this species of fried round dough outlets. Small footprint, but with a corner lounge with worn out leatherette sofa and easy chair, and slate accent wall. 

Nice touches, but it comes down to the quality of their bread and butter - their coffee and sweet dough. In this they cannot complete with the new wave of cafes, bakeries and donut specialty houses that are working harder for my dollar. In the last two weeks I have tasted far better java, and munched on way more luxurious cakes and dough fry around town and the burbs, than sampled last night. Maybe a little more money, but the difference in quality is patent. Too, they don't sweep the floor around you while sitting down to enjoy their wares. No one likes dust and dirt flying around their food. No one wants to feel swept out. 

DD. Too much of a no longer great thing. Becoming stale; much like day old donuts.

Crystal Diner (formerly Edgewater Queen) in Edgewater Park, NJ, is a small footprint roadside attraction on southbound Route 130. It looks recently renovated with stone and stainless fascade, and has a cozy if crowded ambiance. I sat down at the end of the counter and was immediately welcomed by a few of the staff hustling their platters and coffee pots. 

The menu was a tour de force of traditional diner cuisine with several pages just for breakfast. I went with something small (I thought) before a more elaborate and expensive meal. The breakfast sandwich (sausage, egg & cheese on kaiser) seemed about right. I asked my server if they used quality rolls as opposed to the poor varieties found in some kitchens. She assured me theirs were good. 

They weren't.

What arrived minutes later was a large plate, half of which was loaded with home fried potatoes, and a transected sandwich with long toothpicks holding the two halves together. I didn't mind that they used links rather than patties, even when they began to roll out of the sandwich. No biggie. However, the kaiser was a cheap imitation of an actual bakery product. It was crushed, lifeless and tasteless. What was worse were the home fries. They lacked flavor and were dry beyond redemption. Not even salt, pepper and hot sauce could salvage them. It was obvious that the kitchen didn't have a clue and that management was likely part of the conspiracy. 

When was the last time anyone sampled their offerings to provide quality control? Not often enough. 

It was a full house, so I expect I am whistling in the wind, but it is one and done for me.

Robert Morris, a signer of the Declaration of Independence, The Articles of Confederation and the Constitution, left his name to this old river burg, and even had his home, Summerseat, nearby. It was his plan to have the capital of the new United States established right here in Morrisville, PA. He was off target by about 25 miles, as the ultimate vote landed our first national city in Philadelphia. Still, Morris was nothing, if not ambitious for his adopted home town (He was born in England, and arrived here as a teenager). 

How would he feel about having a tavern named after him?  He would probably have enjoyed the notoriety of being associated with a dive bar with smoking privileges, but lacking a kitchen for a meal, and even taps for the beer they serve. Bottles and cans only, folks. Yet, he probably would have supped and indulged his muses elsewhere, as the joint has seen better days, and is now far from its prime.  The crowd is friendly, if loud and in its cups. The suds are priced right, and the barkeeps a smiling, tolerate group. 

My aluminum Bud Light (Philly Philly) edition, was $3. Hard to beat that coinage for a long cold one. 

Still, I couldn't escape the sensation that old Robert M., for all his wealth and colonial political power, would have only visited this establishment when he didn't want to be seen by anyone who would recognize him. It is easy to understand why.

This Giant on West Trenton Avenue in Morrisville is the same size as its sisters in Lower Makefield and Langhorne (Newtown), and has more or less the same inventory, but it does feel more dark and dingy than those other stores.  When I shop there, the lack of adequate lighting makes it a bit oppressive to spend much time.  The absence of the smaller, modern, carts available elsewhere, makes it necessary to use the larger, older and rustier pushers that often have gimpy wheels.  

While it wouldn't take much to upgrade this commercial space into a more pleasant facility, the company seems to have decided to leave it as it is.  Perhaps, their lease is coming to an end, or the revenue from this location does not justify the expenditure.  Regardless, aside from the convenience of stopping in here occasionally, I would avoid it and frequent the newer and easier to navigate markets just to the north for the same prices.

Read Whitney A. from Holland review (12/2/12), which mirrors my own. 
The staff is very friendly and fast, the price is reasonable, and the coffee decent. All good things. But, the bagels are not close to being the right texture nor taste. They could be so much better with a little tinkering.  It's not that they are bad, it's just that they miss the target of being really satisfying. 
With so many bagelphiles adrift at the loss of Bagel Junction, Newtown Bagel could become our Shangri-la, and garner our undying devotion and business with a few adjustments.

What Happened to the Copa brand?

Back in the Day, when Copabanana was only down on South Street, I spent my Friday nights after Tai Chi classes at the Painted Bride hanging out with the motley crew at Copa, downing rip roaring 'ritas, and munching fabulous Burgers laden with Pepper Jack Cheese and sliced Jalapenos, with a basket of Spanish Flies fulfilling a post workout greasy comfort food attack, and exchanging stories of daring do.  So very Yin/Yang. I either sat at the bar, in the dining room, or upstairs in the cramped attic before it became a cooler than you microbar. 

Cut to the recent past, and I finally had a couple of opportunities to hit this Copa on Spruce Street, just off Penn's Campus.  Looked great from the outside - loads of colors - and even suggested some happening things within. One stop at the bar for drinks and eats, and another at a small corner table, left me scratching my kep and wondering whether it was my faulty memory, or the joint's loss of verve, that left me feeling that I was in the wrong Copa.  

Yes.  The drinks were still stiff (one was enough for me), but the grub had fallen off a cliff.  My beloved burger memory suffered a rude awakening when I bit into what looked to be the same TexMex heat burger of ancient lore.  What had been a juicy joy had evolved into the proverbial hockey puck.  Hard from over-grilling, well done from inattention, and spiced by over-aged now gray peppers from absent quality control and pride.

 Not once, but on both occasions, I departed a saddened and wistful patron, yearning for the old days when a Copaburger meant joy on a bun.

TWO SLICE SPECIAL REVIEW ONLY

The price at $4.99 for two large slices of pizza and a soft drink was excellent.  The size of the slices was also more than expected. The service was friendly.  The room was small, with only two tables for those who want to eat their pizza just out of the oven when it is at its prime. So, this is basically a take out joint. 

We wanted a quick bite to tide us over until dinner. A slice apiece and sharing the drink was our intention. 

I requested that the reheat be "well done," in order to bring the ingredients back to life after sitting on display. 

What we received were slices that were not hot in the center where the cheese was thickest. That was likely due to the excessive amount of cheese piled onto the pie, out of proportion to the tomato sauce which seemed sparingly used. The result was pizza that could not be picked up by the crust because it was too heavy on the topside.  The taste was weak because of the cheese/sauce imbalance, and perhaps the quality of the cheese and sauce themselves.  The crust would have been improved with a little salt added to the dough.  

Not an impressive effort by Pizza Land.

F. W. Woolworth built a retail empire at the end of the 19th into the mid twentieth centuries, out of the "Five & Dime" store concept. In its heyday it had over 5,000 stores on 4 continents. One of those iconic enterprises was build on Haddon Avenue in downtown Collingswood, NJ. Today, the high tintype ceiling, wood plank floored space is where Sabrina's Cafe holds court. Walking in from the rear parking lot the room feels cavernous and a real blast from the past. 

It sounded that way, too. Without acoustic softening from all the cheap clothing Woolworths used to sell, the crash and clang of scraping chairs, dozens of conversations, kitchen noise and background music, made for very discordant uncomfortable ambience. If they hung tapestries rather than blackboards, and placed sound panels strategically along the ceiling, Sabrina's would be a much more pleasant restaurant to visit and hang out. As it is, regardless of food quality it is not welcoming enough to be worth a return.

What about my breakfast last week? Well, it left a lot to be desired. My server was pleasant and efficient, but never brought the milk requested with their good coffee. She probably couldn't hear me. Their signature Challah thick cut french toast looked great, but the egg/sugar/cinnamon mix had not penetrated into the body of the slices, making it dry and tough chewing. There was sweetness baked into the bread, but even melted butter and poured syrup did not significantly reduce its lack of moisture within. I took half home thinking I might be able to salvage it in my kitchen, but by the next morning it had lost all freshness and couldn't be revived. RIP. 

I wonder what good old Frank Winfield Woolworth would do about this situation? It was he and his brother Charles who added the lunch counters to their successful stores and made them a new part of American culture. They would no doubt figure out how to perfect the experience and make more money doing it right.

Although I'm sure they had something else in mind in naming this Chinese fast food establishment at the corner of Castor Avenue and Unruh Street in Northeast Philly, that " Boom" can signify the other side of explosive pleasurable cuisine, and be something quite the contrary. Unfortunately, that was where our experience cratered. 

We stopped in for late lunch around 3 when part of the menu shifted from lunch to dinner prices. As all ordering is done online even when sitting in the restaurant, it made for some confusion in both ordering and paying. To make matters worse, there were two menus - a paper menu on the tables and a very different online ordering menu, that were not well coordinated. 

So, while we wanted and thought we ordered beef soup with dumplings; what we got was just poorly crafted dumplings with thick skin and low flavor. Disappointing. Beyond that, the Vietnamese style spring rolls @$3.95 for twins, was mostly cabbage within. Double whammy!  Finally, the beef sandwich was basically a soft scallion pancake rolled up with "meat" inside and a squirt of hoisin sauce for sweetener. While the best of the bunch, it left alot to be desired. 

No doubt this Boom Buns is primarily a takeout joint, and customers are far away when they open the bag and see what they got (BOOM!) For those of us eating in house, the sound of deflated expectations created a rumbling crash in our stomachs (BOOM)! 

Maybe the Xao Long Bao is the way to go here, but we'll never know, because a return visit is just not in the cards. There is too much competition in this growing Asian neighborhood for anyone to give Boom Buns a second try. 

DOUBLE BOOM!!

Of the limited Chinese options in the Newtown area, this place is by far the worst. 
Strictly take out unless you want to sit at one of the two odd sized tables covered with newspapers. 
Several Guangzhou brothers operate this relocated tiny shop.  The kitchen is in full view, and it is not always pleasant to watch how the food prep is done. 
As someone else suggested, this is a place to go only when all the alternatives are blown away by a storm.

Standard Dunkin outlet, perhaps in need of some TLC to spruce it up. My evening stop for a jolt of joe and sweet round dough found  their front doors in need of hydraulic repair to keep them from crashing back behind me, and in need of a sweeping. 

Service was fine. The coffee decent. The donuts forgettable. 

Just back from Southern California where independent donut shops abound. I wonder why that niche market hasn't taken off here? That competition would be great and raise the donut bar to new creative sugary heights.

Stopped in to kill both time and hunger while waiting for an order to be ready at a nearby shop. 

From the outside, it seemed to be a nice looking facility for dinner. As I drove around I noticed an older edifice behind the main building which looked like a simple pizza parlor with a soft ice cream window. I ordered a slice of their Margarita Pizza and Regular to get a sampling of both their standard and specialty pies.  The two plus a 12 oz. drink was under $6. Much less than I was used to paying farther north.  

Unfortunately, the slices were overly oily and I had to let the olive juice run off onto the nice ceramic plate.  The tip of each slice folded when lifted, requiring my index finger to lift it up to get it into my mouth.  Thus, it failed my first test of a good slice - the ability to stand firm without wilting.  Next, the taste.  Aside from being very hot, the sauce and cheese were nondescript.  The bottom crust was not crisp despite the reheating, and the texture was not quite right.  The second prong of the pizza slice test was also a fail.  To compound the problem, I was not provided with utensils to use to hold and cut the slices; something required by the behavior of the soft wedges. 

This area of Fairless Hills has a multitude of Tomato Pie stores.  I am surprised that Arosso's did not come close to competing with the best of them.

As the old saying goes, " Anything worth doing is worth overdoing."
This perfectly sums up Redberry in Village of Newtown Shopping Center.  There are many franchises out there, and all are about the same, with only slight differences in flavors, textures, and toppings.  Here, the flavors seem tamped down.  The Country Vanilla was weak, and the Pumpkin more like nutmeg and Cinnamon, than real pumpkin.  The toppings are all sugary and add too many calories to be healthy.  
The environment is very bright and bare bones.  No comfortable place to sit other than plastic chairs and small tables. Take out is certainly the message here. 
It would be interesting to compare the calories here with the real ice cream places nearby.  For my taste buds, and someone who loves yogurt, Redberry is an underwhelming experience, although my young son likes it .
At approximately $5. per serving with toppings, it is not a cheap treat.

McCaffery Supermarkets recently opened another store at the site of the former Genuardis Supermarket.
They have upgraded it considerably, and it is a very pleasant environment for food shopping.
However, the prices have gone up and they are not really competitive with the Acme in the same shopping area, nor the new Giant that replaced Clemens last year.
I went through it a few months ago, and realized that all the things I normally purchase were more expensive there than the other two venues. 
I don't go there any longer, as any of the specialty items they carry that are not in the others markets, can be found in abundance at Whole Foods with more variety and an even nicer experience.

Another boring supermarket. They are mostly indistinguishable from each other.  Only the signs out front let you know where you are. 

Lack of real competition makes Acme a dull boy.  Same holds true for Giant and McCaffery's. They would all be empty warehouses if Trader Joe's, Whole Foods or Wegman's came to town. 
 
Don't we deserve better?

Lovely to look at, but impossible to love. 

The setting alongside Lake Afton is as pretty as a postcard, but the 3 car parking lot is ridiculously inadequate. It makes a difficult traffic location that much worse, forcing people to focus on parking rather than driving.  Double and illegal parking happen every day, creating a dangerous condition. Amazing that the Yardley government permitted Star$$$ to do this.  

The coffee is the same as everywhere else, which to me is poor to average for the basics, but decent if you fall prey to the insidious upsell pressure to go latte or capp in order to be able to imbibe the burnt tasting brew. 

The facility is pleasant once inside, with windows facing Main Street or the lake. It is also a front row seat to the near miss accidents that routinely happen there.

Super Wok?

This one table takeout joint is the opposite of "Super."  The floor is crammed with inventoried cases of soda and packaging, suggesting it has not been cleaned in forever.  

I went with the quick Lunch Special @ under $6. The price would be right if only the taste followed suit. Everything came out in plastic or Styrofoam containers.  The Wonton Soup was salty (MSG), the wontons themselves, thick and tasteless.  The General Tso's Chicken had a dark tawny gloopy sauce that was neither spicy, nor subtly sweet; but in some no man's land in between that satisfied neither end of the spectrum expected for that dish.  The Fried Rice was the best part of the meal.  It was not cooked in dyed bullion, but had lots of chunky pork and veggies, and little flavor.  Almost decent. 

The advertising declares that it is, "Szechuan, Hunan, Cantonese & Thai Style."  Actually, what they meant to say was that it is none of those.  Not a big mistake.  It is a mish mosh of indistinct tastes and textures, none of which begin to be authentic.  It is not possible to get anything Thai on the Lunch Special, Special Platters, House Specialties nor Combination Platters menus.  There is a "Thai Style" list, but after watching and listening to the kitchen action, I would not recommend going there. 

Super Wok? Super Not!.

What happened?!

Pat's was always the place to go for a decent breakfast at budget prices.  Something is amiss.  
Today's breakfast was still inexpensive, but the quality of the meal was really unacceptable.  

I ordered one of the breakfast specials on the back of the breakfast menu. Two slices of French Toast, Bacon and Coffee @ $5.20.  This is what was served by the pleasantly attentive server:

~ Yellow dyed bread with barely any egg absorbed into it, grilled and tasteless, but for the Smucker's packaged syrup that had to used completely as it continually disappeared into the thick slices.  No sugar added to induce caramelization. No vanilla added for flavor.  

~ The two bread slices stuck together on the plate edge to edge, as it must have grilled, with no effort by the kitchen to separate them for better cooking or more attractive display on the plate. 

~ Bacon deep fried rather than placed on the grill, so that it was tough to chew and tasted of the oil it cooked in.  

~ Decent coffee. 

Maybe it was a mistake to order a breakfast special because management sees it as a loss leader and puts almost no effort into preparing it correctly, or it wants to discourage people ordering it a second time. Regardless, it was a major disappointment, and showed a true dismissiveness toward the patrons. 

But for the fact that I have gone to Pat's over many years, I would not choose to return.  If I find myself there again, I will order a la carte and see what I get.

That's quite a lot of braggadocio for a tiny Chinese takeout shop on the bad side of Brunswick Avenue in Trenton, NJ. Actually, there is no good side in that part of town. Of course, it is just advertising; meaning that none of that name is true. 

This chop shop is state of the art dumpy and depressing. The woman at the order station is friendly enough, but the kitchen help spends a lot of time staring out at the customers. Just a little weird. Whether eating in or taking away, the food is served in the same closed take out containers. Plastic and styro all the way. Chinese tea? Bring yours from home. 

It's not that the grub is bad, it is about average for a joint that doesn't much care about you, and assumes you know nothing about Chinese/American food. The wonton soup, pork egg foo young and fried rice were recognizable by sight and taste. Yellow dye chicken stock, thick skinned dumplings, day old yellow chunky rice - just the way they taught them in mail order cooking school.  

Edible, but forgettable.

Wild Ginger III in the Logan Square Shopping Center, New Hope, has a great name and suggests a deep excursion into the jungles of Southeast Asia. The layout of the restaurant reinforced that sensibility with huge tropical fish tanks and beautiful blue, green and indigo neon lit walls and ceiling. 

It is an auspicious beginning for a new guest, although the fishy smell permeating the room from both the tanks and sushi bar do detract from the gestalt somewhat. Unfortunately, that is not where the disappointment ends. 

I was there for the Thai and Chinese offerings of its fusion menu. Tom Kar (lemongrass/coconut milk soup), Pad Kee Mao and Szechuan Beef were my choices. I planned to eat the first two in house and take the third home for later consumption by the family working until later that evening. I like spicy dishes unadulterated forward the western pallette, so I asked for the hottest rendition available. I wasn't kidding, but the kitchen didn't believe me. 

The soup had plenty of fresh veggies and sweet coconut juice, but lacked the kick of lemongrass. It wasn't in the pot!  Rather than red chili infused broad drunken noodles in a super heated brown sauce, what I got was actually sweet to my tongue, without a hint of the desired fire. I had to send it back to be reworked. It returned, the same noodles, but with some chili sauce or ground Szechuan red peppers or paste mixed in. It wasn't integrated, but I spun it for a moment and it was acceptable. Shame, because the noodles, veggies and chicken were all tender and done well. 

At home we dug into the Szechuan Beef over rice. Again, it looked great and properly wokked, but without a sign of red chili pepper. It was hot as requested, but the burn came from chili powder or paste thrown into the sauce that attached itself to the meat far more that the broccoli, onions and green peppers. Not bad, but clearly prepared by a kitchen lacking the right ingredients to actually produce a Szechuan dish correctly. 

Disappointing.

Wild Ginger is a misnomer. "Mild Ginger," is closer to the truth. Another case of Asian confusion, not fusion.

Tutti Frutti is a frozen yogurt shop in the Oxford Valley Plaza; the same commercial center that holds Bone Fish Grill.  The set up is a bit strange.  Upon walking in, there were a couple of tables and a shelf on the wall with paper cups for the yogurt.  However, the actual handles for dispensing the cool sweetness were in the perpendicular wall and not visible from the entrance.  Beyond that lies the toppings bar and cashier.  The back of the store cannot see the front, nor the machines without cameras.  Def not designed for functionality, nor safety.

The Yogurt?  There were five or six double machines capable of independent pouring or a mix of the two.  I opted for the French Vanilla, Peanut Butter and Cookies & Cream, with room for some blackberries, mini-Reece's, and wet pecans.  

Unfortunately, none of them had much taste.  The vanilla was completely invisible on the tongue.  The peanut butter was recognizable, but weak.  The cookies & cream offered a glimpse of chocolate cookie, but the cream was absent without leave.  Not sure how the store manages to mess up the recipes, or maybe that is what is expected.  Not nearly as good as just eating regular yogurt.  

There are many excellent ice cream alternatives in this area (Dairy Delight, Jo-Jo's, even Friendly's, to name a few), that it makes little sense to seek out Tutti Frutti for dessert decadence.   

"So Fresh"  "So Light"  "So Tasty" ?

Not So Much.

TWO SLICE LUNCH REVIEW

Despite receiving the "well done" reheat as requested, I was less than satisfied with the quality of the pizza served up at Nina's on Bridgetown Pike, Feasterville-Trevose, PA. 

Most significantly, the balance of cheese to red sauce was way off. There was a ton of low grade mozzarella releasing oil and dripping on the plate, and the mass of fromage on top made the undercarriage too weak to hold the weight, causing sag from the get go. Too, the sauce, such as it was, was overwhelmed by the copious cheese, so that the only available flavor on the tongue was of salt. Not pleasant. 

Service was fine and efficient. The dining room was partially open for sit down dining, with chairs on top of tables elsewhere in the room. 

I didn't sample anything else on the menu, but Nina's is a No-No if looking for decent tomato pie, at least of the reheated variety.

Aptly named Jersey diner on Rt. 206, Mt. Holly, NJ. 

The place appears clean and well maintained.  All the marble shines from polishing. The staff in black shirts and red ties look like a well oiled machine.  I sat at the counter for a late breakfast.  The service was friendly, but a little bit off.

I ordered a short stack of French Toast, with a side of Sausage and Coffee.  The Bunnomatic brew was good, and my request for milk rather than Mini-Moo was well met.  The egged bread was a thicker, egg based loaf with the consistency of Chollah, but not actually that species. It grilled up well with lots of caramelized edges and a huge capacity to soak of the Smucker's Syrup.  Wish they had a Maple Syrup alternative, but guess not. Glad it was only two slices, as they were big and filling. 

The breakfast sausage was four links that seem to have been cooked in the deep fryer rather than on the grill or in a pan.  They were uber oily and had a strange taste, perhaps from whatever had been deep fried prior to my order.  I tried, but could only eat half with max effort. Not good. 

I received my bill before I was finished from an escaping server who wished me a good day, but never offered a second mug of coffee.  I had to ask one of the other women behind the counter for more, and she sweetly obliged.  This small slight of courtesy set my attitude toward the place.  Plenty of potential, but lack of execution; especially in human interactive skills and short cuts taken to save time/money, but disrespect the paying public. 

This is one Pandora's Box I will not be opening again.

Number 1 Chinese Restaurant on Parkside Avenue, Ewing, NJ., is classified at the apex of an imaginary list of Chinese houses.  Only if you hold that list upside down will it come close to the top. 

This is strictly a takeout and delivery joint with good reason. If you walk in as I did to order and pick up your own food, you will discovery that it is unkempt with a layer of grime throughout. Not a pleasant place to wait.  The menu and prices are about what you would expect for a low budget kitchen.  The lunch specials are all under seven bucks for a pile of stale fried rice and choice of soup or egg roll in addition to the main offering.  

I found my orange chicken to be small pieces of clucker, thickly breaded and wok fried so that it was not always possible to discern the actual chicken within its cocoon. As indicated, the fried rice was at least a day old, underheated, clumpy and dyed with whatever bouillon they cooked it with. The sauce was thick and gloopy, but the flavor was not so bad.  The overall experience just left much to be desired. 

The only saving grace was the egg roll, which was actually better than expected, with pork strips within in addition to cabbage and spouts. 

Not the place I would return to unless it was the only game in town.

If "A-Okay" is interpreted as mediocre, Siam Cuisine Thai Restaurant III, fits the definition. Although, "Meh," is also appropriate in some regards. Simply, I expected more from this outpost of Southeast Asian dishes, especially after dining in the past at its sister restaurants in the area, and the fabulous Thai meal eaten a few months ago in Metuchen, NJ. 

Here, although the atmosphere was comfortable, the service and quality of the food left much to be desired. 

We ordered three soups; Coconut, Lemongrass and Vegetable.  While the flavor of the coconut soup was accurate, it and the other bowls were populated mostly by broccoli florets, carrot slices and nearly tasteless mushrooms. The lemongrass was mildly spicy hot despite our request that all our dishes be heavy on the chili and other condiments.  Sadly, the veggie offering was just a weak diluted consume with the same contents.  Disappointing.

The entrees were also a mixed bag.  The drunken noodles were plentiful, but not hot enough.  The stuffed chicken breast plate was decent, but would have been much superior with a more spicy stuffing. My salmon dish was a nice fillet, but slightly past its prime.  Again, that broccoli and carrot thing.  Service was slow, and perhaps the bottleneck in the kitchen explained the lack of any attempt to accommodate our requests for spicier food.  However, given that our dinner for four came to nearly $100 with a beer and a couple of non-alcoholic drinks, they could have either made a stronger effort, or let us know in advance that they were unable to satisfy our requests. 

Regardless, given the other Thai houses in and around Bucks County, there is no reason to visit Siam Cuisine again anytime soon.

2.5 Stars

WHOLE PIE PIZZA REVIEW -

Stopped at Giuseppe's for late lunch after a beautiful walk around at Morris Arboretum. It was about half way home. Perhaps with eyes bigger than stomach, we went with a large pie, half pepperoni, thinking a fresh baked pizza would be more satisfying than reheated slices and we could take the rest home. 

It didn't quite work out as planned. 

Upon delivery to our table by the friendly server, we noticed a small pool of oil sitting mid pie. We blotted up as much as we could, but it remained shiny with the excretions from the pepperoni and low grade mozza covering the crust. 

The request for a "well done" finish to make the undercarriage as firm as possible wasn't honored, so each slice drooped down when lifted and continued to drip oil. The cheese layer was too thick to be supported, and there wasn't any balance with the sauce, which was a bit salty for our buds. 

Just not a very strong effort. Made us rue our decision and wish we had gone with a couple of slices, or better yet, not stopped in at all.

The space was modern, yet comfortable. Black tables, wood-like floors.  A nice diner-esque counter. HD TV on the wall.  Menu full of creative alternatives in the pancake, French toast, waffle and omelet genres.  

Perhaps I made a mistake in ordering a simple Short Stack of French Toast.  It seemed as soon as I gave the friendly server my order she was coming back with it already mixed, dipped, grilled and plated.  Olympic turn around time. 

But, something went wrong.  The four wedges were not fully cooked.  The toast was mushy and not hot in its core. There was no crispy caramelization.  It had been rushed for no apparent reason other than inattention.  Time constraints did not permit returning it to the grill for a few extra minutes, so I ate what I could and took my leave. 

With so many good reviews, mine is surely an outlier.  I will try again in a few weeks and see what I get.  But for now, I have certainly had much better French Toast at many places in the area.

This is an older version of Friendly's on West Trenton Avenue, Morrisville, Pa.  The dining area is long and narrow, with about twenty tables and booths. It is an attractive space in a 1960's kind of way; feeling like a joint your parents would have enjoyed in their teens. 

Adrianna was a fine server;  friendly, prompt, attractive.  Her red hair worked for her. She took my order of a patty melt, and like a skilled salesperson, inquired if I wanted fries, or the ninety-nine cent upgrade to onion rings.  What the hey?! I splurged.  She also thought that I might qualify for the free sundae, and delicately broached the topic with diplomatic flair.  In fact, I did.

Everything tasted good on the way down.  The melt had the appropriate finish and a goodly amount of grease.  The rings were uber-crisp.  The black raspberry scoop with KitKat crumbles looked strange, but tasted fine.  In fact, when I walked out I was considering a three/four star review.  That was until I went to bed a few hours later.  By that time, my stomach was in distress, and I feared a sleepless regurgitative night.  

It was a close call, but a handful of Tums quieted the restive beast, and I finally slept somewhere around 2 am.  

I'm all for low budget burgers, but I suspect the raw beef may have spent too much time above health department temperature requirements before being slapped on the grill.  Besides, this meal came to almost $12, with grat.  At those prices, I don't want to deal with unpleasant consequences.

Unfortunately, the first observation from my dealing with Pho & More in Montgomery Commons is that while it may be a Vietnamese house, it certainly is not a Thai kitchen. As I ordered from both ends of the menu, I found myself happy with the Roast Pork Banh Mi sandwich, but damned dissatisfied with the Lemongrass Coconut Soup (Tom Kha) and the Drunken Noodles (Pad Kee Mao). 

Why? Because although both those dishes have lemongrass spice as the key ingredient, there was absolutely no lemongrass to be found in either the soup, nor the wide flat rice noodles. The soup tasted of watered down coconut milk, with ample chicken and mushrooms, but without the strong bite that lemongrass provides. Very poor effort. 

And the Drunken Noodles were not hot and chewy at all, but really just Chinese Vegetable Chow Fun with a few leaves of Thai basil mixed in. I ordered it "very spicy," and the cashier dude repeated that request to me upon pickup. Yet, despite the reasonable quantity of noodles and veggies, it totally lacked the heat punch desired. Boring, semi-sweet fat noods without redeeming fire signature. Major disappointment. 

If I had to guess, I would venture that there was not a Thai person in the kitchen, nor even a real authentic recipe for Bangkok cuisine in the house. If they don't have lemongrass in stock, they just aren't Thai, and shouldn't misrepresent their abilities. Yet, the Banh Mi was decent and I grant that someone may have trained in Ho Chi Minh City or Hanoi to perfect their pho stock. 

Had I known the truth about this joint, I would have happily stayed in Vietnam, and travelled to Thailand another day. As it is, with dishonesty at their core, I will never return to find out what they are really good at. 

Fooled me once, shame on you!
Fool me twice; never happen!

Aside from being the only DD I know that has converted floor space into a fire pit leather sofa lounge, there is nothing out of the ordinary in this shop.  The coffee is hot. The donuts sweet. The service so-so.  The lounge full of Russian 20 somethings. 
If any of these appeal to you, this is the place for you.
Me?  Not so much.

The merger with Continental Airlines may have been good for United, but it has not been a blessing for its passengers. Where Continental offered excellent people up front and in the aisles, quality entertainment options with the self-programming movie and music system, and decent food on international flights, the "new and improved" version is anything but.  Gone are the useful menus; replaced by, "Chicken or fish," without further information.  Gone are the stopby's to see how you are doing.  Now, the flights are sterile.  

It is obvious that problems with management are spilling into customer services. Even the introductory videos with Jeff Whomever seem bland and not designed to offer even a sincere gratitude for flying with them.  In fact, in the video on the plane to Beijing, he seemed gaunt and suffering a health problem.  Hope he hasn't been spending too much time inflight, because often after one of these 14 hour jobs, I feel just like he looks.

The best thing about this Starbucks on Main Street, Doylestown, is the front elevation from the street. It occupies a historic building that dominates a key intersection in the Borough.  Very attractive. 

Sadly, that is where the positives end.  Inside, the layout is dreary. Dark on the brightest days, it feels like a morose ghost inhabits it, making for a sense of weariness. The coffee at all Star$$$ is universally bad, and it is no different here. It forces you to upgrade to an expensive alternative to regular coffee, a perverse upsell that seems to work everywhere. The pleasantness of the staff is helpful, but cannot overcome the down energy that is ever present. 

Many better choices in town, perhaps why the shop was not overly busy while life on the streets around it was jumping.

My first visit to any Home Goods occurred yesterday when returning a gift.  After securing the store credit I walked around the space to see if I could find something of equal value while there to avoid the need for a return visit. 

I couldn't, and walking around this downscale sibling of TJ Maxx was actually rather depressing.  Lots of junque. No real value. 

Big brother has more useful things.  Luckily the store credit extends to all members of this retail family.

Slice & Soft Drink Review

Walked in to Yordana II tonight for a light bite and went with a slice of regular pizza that was sitting under glass. The place was empty but for me at 7:15. It had about a half dozen booths along the inside wall.  It was a clean house, with three guys in the kitchen. Everyone was polite. 

I asked that the reheat be "well done," to bring the wedge fully back to life. The young cashier took my $4 and handed me some change for the tip jar on the counter. I went to pour my drink and retreated to a booth to await my victuals. 

It arrived a few minutes later in the hands of the chef. It was a smallish slice, but I wasn't starving. My standard for good pizza wants the point to stand firm when picked up by the crust. It demonstrates a well baked and strong chassis upon which the rest of the vehicle is built. This one collapsed on elevation. The weight of the cheese and the trapped moisture in the underbaked bottom made for a soggy base. 

I folded it over longitudinally to hold it together, and a rivulet of oil rolled off onto the paper plate. Cheap cheese. When I could finally take the first bite, the triangle was hot enough to melt the surface and warm the undercarriage, but had not reached full reheat, let alone the heavier burn I requested. Also, the top was almost entirely cheese with a thin tasteless layer of sauce. Bad proportions. 

This was not a good pizza for me. Everyone has a different preference for their pie, but when requests are not honored, the problem goes deeper than lack of real experience with a classic American comfort food. It is about listening and translating that request into the desired product. This just wasn't done. 

Everything else on the menu may be great, but the pizza reheat was not.

Strictly a low budget primarily take out joint that dishes out the standard Chinese/American fare at low prices.  Nothing original here, except they do provide hot tea in a large heated pot for those who ask for it.  Many places are so stripped down that only cold drinks are offered with lunch specials, and the iconic Chinese tea is forgotten.  

The room was chilly for eating in as I did, making it obvious they did not encourage people hanging around to eat on their one or two tables.  Health issues were also present, as I observed the chef breading chicken pieces with his bare hands before dropping them into the wok.  Hate to think where those digits may have been.  

The taste of my Sesame Chicken with Fried Rice was okay, although the rice had been made earlier with a yellow dye chicken broth.  I didn't expect it to be made to order.  Same was true for the Wonton Soup.  Thick skins and unidentifiable meatish food within.  Bad texture. Worse taste.  I left most of that plastic container behind.  

How much better it would be if these places provided real plates and flatware, rather than plastic containers and utensils, for those few who chose to eat there.  Being served as if ordering take out just seems dismissive of those customers.  It doesn't change the taste of anything, but sure makes for a "we don't care about you," attitude.

This review is for the lunch experience at Hong Kong Gourmet. 

The 5 Star reviews caught my attention, so even though it was a longer drive to Richboro to get to the location in Crossroads Plaza, I thought it was worth the time.  Walking in, I viewed a nice dining room with the ubiquitous leatherette booths and industrial carpet, and it was bright and airy.  The house was empty at 1:45, not unusual for a late lunch. There were two women working the floor.  They seemed tired, but dutiful.  I was pointed to a booth near the front and handed a menu.  

After perusing the multi-page document and seeing a fairly broad selection of dinner dishes that were appealing, I finally reached the "Lunch Special" page in the back.  Although there were 24 items listed with a price range between $5.50 and $8.95, most listings were of the, "chicken/pork/beef with veggies/nuts/garlic/lobster sauce and fried rice," variety.  Uninspired.  All the better dishes were in other parts of the menu at much higher price points (read; dinner prices).  This approach certainly made me feel that lunch was not important to this business, unless I was willing to eat dinner earlier in the day.  

Okay.  I was there. I was put off.  I would play it out.  I ordered the General Tso's Chicken, which had a little red pepper icon next to it.  It came with Hot and Sour Soup, and Pork Fried Rice.  The soup was not bad. Plenty of tofu, sprouts, and slivers of pork. Not too much vinegar.  The Fried Rice was a pleasant surprise.  It was fresh with chunks of pork and a nice supply of veggies. However, the Chicken came in thinly breaded cubes and rectangles, was dry tasting, and the sauce was neither sweet nor spicy.  There was only a hint of flavor in the thin glurb. Pieces of Green Pepper were thrown on top of the chicken, and while it was fresh, it was monochromatic.  I get that they did not want to invest heavily in my lunch, but why not a little red and yellow bell peppers, too?  

My read from the experience, which included non-smiling service and the delivery of my check while I was still eating, was that Hong Kong Gourmet does not want to do lunch, and is only open at those hours to catch the unwary. I deduced that the soup and rice were good because they were prepared in advance of dinner, not for the lunch crowd.  Their evening victuals may well be better, but after this exposure of disinterest, why would anyone want to give them another visit?  

I certainly won't.

I now know the downside of having a pizza parlor make pies for display purposes.  If you are unfortunate enough to come in for a late pizza slice lunch, you end up eating old pizza from the display, rather than anything remotely fresh.  

I learned this lesson the hard way a few days ago, when I stopped in after 2:30 for a small repast to tide me over until dinner.  My Tomato Pie was sauce without cheese (In my world it is sauce over cheese). It was okay, but basically too acidic from sitting around for many hours.  Too, the plain slice while large, had an overworked crust that proved tough and chewy rather than crisp as a cracker.  Time had not been kind to it.

I liked the gentleman who prepared my slices in the oven and brought them to the table, and it was not his responsibility to make a new pie for me.  Still, there outta be a rule that says display pizzas are dumped after being out in the open for more than 2 or 3 hours, so they are not reheated beyond human tolerances.

Moish & Itzy's and its predecessors have been serving me breakfast and an occasional dinner for almost 20 years.  However, I frequent there less over time for a variety of reasons.  When I found myself there last week for a breakfast meeting, I had a few moments to look around, read the menu closely, and get in touch with what I have liked about M & I.  

The physical plant looks worn.  Walls dinged; molding dented and chipped; dirty carpets; same old floor plan. The menu is still huge, but unchanging.  The prices fail to reflect the economic realities of our times, nor the effort of other restaurants to offer  less expensive options.  Finally, I compared my memory of decent food with current fare.  That was basically the same from what I could tell.  Big BUT - when I ordered Matzoh Brie (Fried Matzoh) I was told they had no Matzoh!  Okay, but how is that possible in a Jewish style deli? I will skip the fun analogies.  

I ordered the French Toast instead.  It was fine, but uninteresting.  That sort of sums up my current sense of this place.  It looks and feels basically the same, but after so much time in business, perhaps it should do something differently to keep people engaged in the environment.  I felt tired after leaving M & I, despite all the coffee. 

Moish and Itzy felt tired, too.

El Limon, the Mexican Cocina that has expanded locally to 16 shops, has always been a favorite of mine for comida Mexicana in the region. I have visited four or five locations over the years and always found them to be authentic, creative and down to earth in the atmosphere department - utilitarian without painted carved chair ostentation. They are good eats at good prices. 

My recent visit to their new Bensalem store has me reconsidering my past impressions. Maybe they are growing too fast, or their supply lines are stretched too thin by coming into Bucks County from Montgomery, or COVID logistics have overwhelmed them, but the charming delicious gestalt of past exposure was not present in this place. 

I ordered a Torta Milanese (thin breaded fried beef sandwich) and Horchata rice drink. I've had both before at their other locales. Overlooking for the moment that the servers forgot to set up my table with flatware, napkins or glass of water even after delivering my meal, the sammy itself was a shadow of its previous self. Less meat, less chipotle mayo, less avocado, and a kaiser roll from the discount day old shelf at the back of their bakery. It was soft, tasteless and dry. There was no way they used such inferior bread on any other visits; in fact in the past their rolls had stolen the show they were so good. 

Not this time. It was a complete sad sack. 

Clearly, quality control has taken a hit at El Limon Bensalem. They need to step up their training in customer service, and seriously reevaluate their bread purveyor.
 
At least the Horchata was quite good.

Don't know what everyone else has been smoking, but this former corner diner cum Nino's Pizzarama doesn't make very good pies. 

The place sits at the intersection of Chambers and Genesee Streets, a locale that is not designed to make you feel secure.  Through the large dirty windows pass the tempest tossed ravages of Trenton.  The dive is tiny with 5 tables, and floors, walls and windows that have not been washed in who knows how long.  I came in for a couple of slices, and was told by the counterman that the uncut pizza in front of him had just come out of the oven.  

No reason to doubt him.

He tried to fit both slices on a single white paper plate, and when the point of one folded over and began to drip onto his counter, I asked for a second plate to hold both triangles.  He handed me the plate and I slid it under the drooping offender.  I sat down at a booth, sprinkled on the hot pepper flakes, and picked up the first slice.  It had not folded, and the undercarriage was actually thin and quite firm.  It held its point well until I snapped it off with one bite.  

It was indeed hot.  The immediate taste was that of pizza - if a little salty from the cheese, and slick from the oil moistening the surface.  After putting it back on the plate, the oil began to run off the slice and onto the plate and ultimately the table when I picked it up again.  Too much poor quality cheese, and not enough of any quality sauce.  I could not taste it over the shouting of the fromage.  

The second slice, cooler, was no better.  The original damage required a two handed pickup.  The fold where I bent it to be able to pick it up began to run a rivulet of oil, and dripped from the outer rim.  the oily saltiness was the dominant message.  

Just not very good.  The young lads next to me said their cheesesteak was good, so maybe that is the way to go.

Straight pizza slices, certainly wasn't.

If you really like finding your way out of a maze, IKEA is your kind of fun store. One way in. One way out. Little signs with arrows point you in the right direction. A few unmarked shortcuts if your keen enough to find them. 

It's not that their products aren't good; they are. It's not that their Swedish meatballs aren't excellent; they are. It's all about their concept of how people think and learn. To IKEA, customers are to be lead around through the entire warehouse regardless of what they need, and forced to pass through every department on two floors until finally reaching check out cashiers at the end of a long and boring stroll. Once you've begun, forget about going back to the beginning. The human undertow will just drag you down. Need a restroom? Good luck with that. 

It helps if you are a zombie or dyed in the wool shopper when dealing with IKEA. If you don't particularly like the "Costco" warehouse experience, this place will wear you down. I mean, how many DIY furniture projects do you have in one lifetime? How often do you need to build shelves for your office? Not nearly enough to make this entertaining. 

Yeah. We did buy a few glass water containers for around the house, and the prices were good. But, how much better it would have been to be directed to the location where they were shown, and be able to go right to them, than be required to go on safari to find them. 

What a perverse trade-off.

Reading through the more recent reviews of the Continental Tavern I had the impression that while most people liked the atmospherics, they were less enthused with the cuisine. While the two of us only had their "Best of Bucks" burgers, fries and soft drinks, we departed thinking we have had better elsewhere.

This is the Shake Shack inside King of Prussia Mall, in the second floor food area. 

I admit to being the last person on Earth to eat at Shake Shack, despite it's siren song of awesome burgers, fries and signature shakes. Now that I have finally had the pleasure of dining at this outlet in the fantabulous KoP Mall I can honestly say that I am happy to have the experience in my life, but really don't understand the halabaloo. 

Aside from long lines and slick advertising, I found the burgers to be rather pedestrian (not that there is anything wrong with walking). A single puck sandwich seems to be 5 ounces of overcooked beef in a pretty good bun, lettuce, tomato and secret sauce. At most, a four biter. Just about every tavern in the Universe does a better one. My backyard grill puts theirs to shame. Most roadside joints have nothing to fear from this outfit. 

True, the shakes are a kick in the pants, so maybe the burgers just accessorize the superior drink and are not designed to be the star of the show. If that is the intention, they have succeeded. The salted caramel shake far outshined it's burger cousin. 

But, do I want to pay $6 for a small shake on a regular basis? No. I can do better at DQ on both counts, for far less money. 

For me, Shake Shack is an exercise in hypnotic marketing, akin to the Emperor's New Clothes fairytale. 

Caveat Emptor!

Okay.
Don't judge me harshly.
It was late.  I was really hungry.  This Wendy's is close to my office.  I needed to get something quick to eat at my desk. 
There it was.  Brash. Loud. Unrepentant. Singing its siren song. ("Come to me in your weakness and famishment...I will sustain you, at least for today...")
I drove onto the drive thru line. Someone pulled in right behind me.  I could not get out if I wanted. I was trapped...or was I willingly caught?!  The big menu board was in front of me.  Seductively swaying in the cold rain, I was mesmerized.  I ordered, I paid. I picked it up at the next window. 
I hoped no one I knew saw me.
Back at the office, I took a bite of Dave's Single Special Combo with Cheese.  Better roll than I remembered.  Was that burger a tad more tasty?  A bit too salty.  Fries  lacking spine to hold straight, and bending like a willow branch in the wind. Also too much sodium chloride.  
In a world in which Burger Culture has evolved several generations from Wendy's to Five Guys and Cheeburger Cheeburger, how can the poor little lass compete.  
In truth, she probably can't, except in those moments of weakness when no other lover is around, and she offers her tiny hand with a vanilla frosty.

TWO SLICE LUNCH REVIEW

Stopped in to Special Pizza City on Olden Avenue Extension in Ewing, NJ, today for a quick lunch on a beautiful day. Plenty of parking, but a surprisingly small footprint inside with tables crowded together requiring side sliding to reach those against the wall. 

I asked for a regular slice and one Brooklyn square, well done. Order taken with a smile. Seven dollars and change. Looked good on the paper plates. Bigger than average. 

The undercarriage of the plain slice was thick and held the topside firmly. First bite was a heavy crunch through a thick crust and formidable layer of cheese. Nice, but neither the crust, cheese, nor red sauce layer had much flavor. The balance of cheese and sauce was out of whack, with way too much yellow and too little red. Then, half way through the wedge, the molten cheese separated from the base and slid in a gooey mass on to the plate.

End of that mess. 

The Brooklyn square was better, but not enough to save the overall experience​. It did not fall apart and had a somewhat better flavor profile, with fresher mozza and basil added on top.  Still, the taste was weaker than available in better Italian tomato pie parlors. 

Trenton has some great pizza shops. This is not one of them.

Dominick's Pizzeria is in the Anchor Crossing Center at the intersection of Rt. 413 and Windy Bush Road in Wrightstown, so don't be confused by the Newtown address shown in many places. 

The entire center was eerily empty on a late Sunday in August. Only Dom's and Happy Panda were open for business. We stopped in for a light bite on the way to Doylestown's County Theater.  I couple of slices of regular pizza and an ice tea were inexpensive at under $5.50.  Friendly counterman. Clean shop. 

The pizza came out of the reheat oven quickly and the cheese had nicely remelted. After sprinkling on crushed chili pepper flakes and allowing some excess oil to drip onto the paper plate the first slice was lifted, folder lengthwise, and brought to mouth. The slice held its form well, with firm crust reinforced by the vertical fold. First test passed.  The tip was hot and the bitten off tip was pleasantly crunchy.  Second test passed. After that, however, the grade began to slip.  The taste test was a weak result, as the sauce was bland and the cheese undistinguished.  It was pizza, but not a strong contender for top rank. 

The second slice compounded the issue by failing to hold form after folding, and sagging in the middle before the tip could be bitten. But, for the chili flakes, the slice would have really left too much to be desired. With the added heat, it was adequate and filling, if uninspired. 

Compared to the other alternatives in Newtown, just a few miles down the road, Dominick's pizza falls below Marcos and Newtown Pizza, and at approximately the same level as Dolce Carini Pizzeria. 

I will return to sample other parts of the menu, but I am in no rush to do so.

Maybe I should have known better when I walked into Pasta On Time, and it was empty of customers. Or maybe, the awful acoustics of the walls and ceiling and loud TVs should have been a tip off that this may not have been the greatest place for a sit down meal. Regardless, I miss those cues, and ordered a full meal of chicken francais, pasta, salad and twist rolls for consumption on the premises.

It wasn't all bad, but neither was it possible to really enjoy it, given what was served. The salad was okay with balsamic vinaigrette, and it can be forgiven that they used iceberg rather than romaine. The FDA had advised throwing all romaine out until they determined that only lettuce from Central California was the source of dangerous leafies. And, the twisted rolls were also pretty good, although two small pieces seemed a little light in the generosity department. 

No, the problem really began and ended with the chicken dish. While the three fillets were sautéed well, the sauce was from another planet. Rather than real lemon and white wine mixed with butter in proper proportion to make a delicious sauce, this combination seemed to use reconstituted lemon juice, no wine, and perhaps salted butter. The result was a awful tasting colloidal yellow soup with a strong bitter lemon flavor that sat on my tongue until I got home to brush my teeth free of it. Rather than savor the taste of my favorite Italian dish, I had to remove as much sauce as possible from the chicken, and avoid the spaghetti beneath all together. 

Maybe a sandwich would have been the way to go, but some of the reviews say otherwise. What was clear, was that the kitchen didn't know how to make this meal, and followed a recipe that lacked any finesse, along with the absence of wine, lemon fruit and sweet butter. 

It was a complete whiff. 

"Pasta On Time," or, Pasta No Time?

This BK sits out on Nottingham Way next to China Express, part of the new commercial zone being developed at the old fairgrounds site. It is designed for drive around service, with a dangerous nod to in house dining. To walk in requires crossing the drive through lanes where most drivers aren't paying attention to pedestrians. 

The drive up ordering system needs help because it is difficult for driver and ordertaker to understand each other. I could not hear what the young guy was saying to me, but it was apparent he didn't hear me well either. I repeated myself three or four times and hoped for the best. I was pleasantly surprised that I received what I asked for. 

I ate at my desk. The breakfast croissant sandwich was small, but decent. The coffee just mediocre. Prices were very close to what is available at the many delis, cafes and morning taverns in the area, so unless time is at a premium, I prefer the other alternatives for higher quality and comfort. 

Searching for a word to capture the experience, "uninspired," seems about right.

This Mario & Franks in Fieldsboro, NJ, is much smaller than number 4 in Trenton, but is nicely finished with a small, but comfy dining room.  Service is fine and prices on lunch specials are downright inexpensive.  

So, when I saw a Chicken Parm Sandwich with Fries and Drink for $6.99, I was tempted.  Unfortunately, the excitement turned to disappointment once I dug in to the huge plate that was served.  Biggest hot sandwich I had seen in a long while.  At least a foot long, cut in half, and a pile of taters that took up the other half of the large square platter. 

To my tongue, the chicken fillets had been frozen and deep fried, rather than pan sautéed, which is the right and tasty way to cook it.  Maybe cheaper to use frozen chicken and fry alongside the potatoes in a vat of common oil, but it sure kills the expectation that comes with ordering any parm dish.  Really did not taste good. 

This was a shortcut to Never Never Land.

Not sure how Chickie's & Pete's is considered a café, as it seems much more like a dark and dingy sports bar with a huge collection of tap levers hanging from walls and exposed beams.  There seems to be plenty of suds to choose from, and the menu is adequate, especially if you like shellfish as your main course.  

Problem here is that there are no side dishes with your meal.  Everything is a la carte, and the expense climbs rapidly.  If you want a beer with that, your tab will gouge you at least $15 for a sandwich lunch.  

My Chicken Parm Sandwich was pretty good; deep fried and crispy outside, still soft and tasty inside.  The Tomato Sauce was mildly salty, but still a good blend.  Would have been even better if they figured out a way to give a small amount of Crab Fries with the platter, rather than charging another $7 for a full basket of taters.  The House Salad @ $10., was a large plate full of Romaine and some other veggies, and a reasonably good vinaigrette, but underwhelming at the price. 

If you're into tired looking sports bars with ample brew (not necessarily craft-quality), and a menu that forces you to be very selective about the cost of your nosh, C & P is for you.  Otherwise, there are much better sports houses around with better food, drinks, atmosphere and prices.

I should have been alerted to the possibility of issues when we walked in near 7 pm on a Sunday evening, and only a few tables were occupied and, none were Chinese.  Yet, I was with my Chengdu friend, and we wanted some authentic Szechuanese hot chow.  How could a place that calls itself, "Traditional Szechuan," and has pandas in their signs, not be prepared to satisfy a true native soul?  

It wasn't.  

Even while the owner sat with us and chatted away about home, the staff delivered our dishes in no particular order and spread them out across our table.  I guess he trusted the kitchen to do everything right, but in retrospect I would have preferred him sweating over the stove assuring that everything presented would make us happy.  

The Dumplings in Chili Oil were large, but tasteless.  The Cold Sliced Beef in Hot Sauce, a delicacy at home, was over salted and gristly, rather than approaching the numbing spiciness desired.  The Fish Fillet with Dry Pepper was the best dish on the table, and the only one that we did not finish and agreed to take home.  The 3 Mushrooms Rice Cake Style was basically a mushroom consume poured over rice cakes prepared to sizzle.  It was decent, but nothing I would want a second time.  Water Spinach with Garlic was fine, but a bit too stemmy when the leaves are the tender delights. 

Given the excellent Szechuan kitchens in the neighborhood (Emai, Four River, Spice-E), and those a little farther afield (Han Dynasty and Chili Szechuan), it is difficult to see how this place will survive.  As we were the last customers in the joint when we left at 8:30, its fate may already be sealed.

This was going to be a one star review until management slightly redeemed itself at the end. 

The story begins when I walked into this Modern Vac & Sew Center on Grant Avenue in Northeast Philly, in need of a power cord and foot petal for a Amazon purchased Singer machine that was delivered by the seller without those parts inside the box.  He didn't have them, and left me to my own devices to find where I could.  Good luck to me!

The folks here looked at the machine and said they would order the parts. They took a $20 deposit.  No sweat. A month later, no call from them, so I rang them up to inquire, and was told the parts had not arrived.  Seemed excessive, but what do I know from sewing machines?  In the meantime, I decided to make a second attempt to find what was needed, and realized there was a local sew and vac in town.  The good people there also checked the machine and thought they could help with securing what was needed.  I told them about the situation, and agreed to only see if they were available, without ordering until I had finished dealing with these guys.  Reasonable strategy.

Two weeks later, still no word, so, I went down to Grant Ave. again.  I asked for status, and the employee there could not tell me anything.  He looked around the shop, but found no parts, nor order for them.  I asked for my deposit back, but he declined to do so before talking to the boss about whether the parts had been special ordered and paid for in advance.  He promised he would call me in two days.  I wasn't happy about leaving without the money, but I calmed down and realized this dude was doing the best he could in these circumstances. 

While I waited, I decided to buy the parts the hometown shop had located at a fair price. Intuition told me this place would not come through for me.  

True to his word, the man at this store called to let me know I could have my deposit back.  He saved a star, and proved himself to be an honorable fella.  Can't say the same for ownership, who never saw the need to contact me about the status of the ordered parts, even after I called to ask about them. Not great customer service. 

Can't read his mind, but he can read this review.

Strictly take out with $10. minimum for credit card purchase.  

The menu is extensive, both Chinese and Sushi, and the prices reflect the absence of tables and service expenses.  The front of the menu has a nice statement about healthy eating being their goal, and that the food is all natural, low calorie and how it is the, "only specialty take out serving authentic Chinese & Japanese in this area." 

Maybe, but what they do not claim is that it is tasty or high quality cuisine.  Sadly, speaking only of the Chinese side of the menu, it is not.  The ingredients may have integrity, but the resultant dishes are ordinary and lacking in most redeeming qualities other than being filling. The food isn't bad, it just isn't very good.  

I wouldn't attempt to compare it with the food produced in New York or Philly, but even by the rather pedestrian suburban standard, Lotus Garden hardly measures up to its peers.  

It may offer gluten free dishes, but by the same token, it also offers tasteless ones. 

Best to keep looking for a more satisfying fast Asian meal.

I have visited four BWWs around the country;  Chino Hills, CA., Flagstaff, AZ., Northeast Philly, and this one.  Not that this is a representative sample, but in my mind, this one is on the bottom of my list.  The distance between locations is matched by the yawning gap between this experience and the others.  

The shop in Flag is large, clean, and a fun place to sit at the bar late into the night while drinking a broad selection of beer and well presented wings and burgers after a run to the Canyon.  Chino Hills has a different sensibility with a more Latin and Asian clientele, but just as much entertainment value and food quality.  Northeast Philly has none of the above, but a more tie off/working stiff/biker vibe, where you can still grab a stool and hang with the boys.  But, the former Don Pablos feels helter skelter.  Perhaps, the ghost of the former tenant haunts the room.  Still, the loudness of the music overlapping the glaring TV's , and a large step down in service and cuisine quality, make this a disjointed, cacophonous experiment.
