Hard to converse, nor enjoy the subtle differentiation between the BBQ sauces. The burgers never come out Medium.  Well Done is the seeming only option. 

While I wouldn't mind the "pay for the label" approach to BWW when the atmospherics are working well, when they don't, the price seems unwarranted and absurd.  As someone who has enjoyed the experience elsewhere, as well as a happy former stockholder, I suggest management get a grip on the quality control issues here, and bring the operation into line.  

Otherwise, change the name to protect the franchise.  How about, "Bungalow Wild Winks?"

No doubt the Trenton Pork Roll Festival could have been something special given the concept and all the vendors and bands that showed up. However, the word is that 2,000 people invited themselves for a 300 person party, and the logistics were just not capable of handling the scene.  Too, a massive thunderstorm in mid afternoon blew out the electricity, shutting down the bands, and dousing everyone and their pork roll sandwiches. The canopies were not able to control the deluge.  

I was there for a few minutes in early evening after the last of the heavy downpour, but not post the straggling showers that seemed to hang over Trenton Social all day.  After standing in line and getting soaked, I decided discretion was the better part of valor, and beat a retreat to find a dry place for dinner.  

Please try again next year, fellas.  You are on to something here.

Two Slice & Coke Review

I was hunting for a missed dinner nosh to spare me those overnight hunger pangs, and Fat Tony's appeared on my Yelp radar. Not many reviews, but you know what they say about 'any port in a storm'. 

Fat T's sits in a small commercial strip right next to an excellent new member of the Morrisville restaurant community. Big window permitted full view of the house with only two deuces on the floor. Clearly a take out operation. But, I like my pizza well done and right out of the oven, so I sat down to await my first bite of Tonypie. 

It wasn't what I hoped. 

Although well done was requested, what I got were two slices without firm chassis that refused to lift off the paper plate when I elevated their crusty end. Saggy and limp. I had to pick up the laggard points and throw them over the thick end, making them more pizza roll, than pizza pie. 

The sauce had promise, but if my slices can't salute when called to attention, they can't serve in my tomato pie army.

Aside from the historic appeal of old railroad cars, New Hope & Ivyland Railroad has nothing going for it. It is a very short run at a very slow speed for a very high price.  I hesitate to label it a tourist rip off for the unaware, but it comes close.  

There are much better alternatives if your want a railroad experience.  If the train ride itself is your reason for going to New Hope, save the time and money and take the Light Rail from Trenton to Camden, or stops in between.  That is an actual passenger commute that rolls along the Delaware River for a while, and stations in some pleasant Jersey towns, like Burlington.  Last stop is the Camden Aquarium. If old railroads are your thing, make the day trip to Scranton, the old railroad capital of the USA. Plenty of museums and operational locomotives pulling plush Pullmans and a working roundhouse. 

The NH & I experience will likely leave you feeling disenchanted.

I needed to return my Dish Network "box," and the instructions received with a shipping container said that a UPS Store could handle the job, and that Dish would cover the cost.  So, I boxed it up with the remote, taped it closed, and drove over to the local UPS Store in the Summit Square Shopping Center in Langhorne, Pa.  

I walked in around 5:30 pm.  The time sign said it was open until 6:30 pm.  I was the only one there, and I did not see an employee until I was near the counter in the rear of the shop.  At that point a woman came out from the back area to see what I wanted.  She saw the box and the telltale return shipping label.  

"You want me to take that?"

"Yes, please. Can you handle this return to Dish?" 

"We can." 

"Great. Thank you."

I placed the box on the counter, and she grabbed it, slid it over the weighing scale, and pushed it to the side.  

 Not another word was exchanged between us.  No "thank you for your business, nor "have a good evening."  She seemed mildly put off that she had to do something without direct compensation from me.  I guess this project didn't deserve any courtesy.  

I shouldn't complain unless the box doesn't arrive at its destination.  But, for all she knew, I planned to return tomorrow with a truck load of business for her. 

Not!

Johnny Apples sits at the bottom of Buck Road, just above the stream that runs through this valley into Neshaminy Creek.  It is a surprisingly large house, with bar and dining room running the front of the building, and a nice patio in the rear. It is casual and comfortable.  The beer list is relatively simple, and the menu offers traditional American fare.  We came in for dinner on Tuesday night when there were few people dining, and only two or three at the bar.  It was cool, and it felt great to get out of the suddenly oppressive heat enveloping southeastern Pennsylvania. 

We ordered a cross section from their offerings.  Avocado burger with fries, blackened shrimp with mashed potatoes, and "The best meatloaf you've ever tasted," with taters and string beans. While all looked good upon arrival, none really lived up to our hopeful expectations. The burger was a previously frozen puck that was cooked beyond the medium requested, and lacked taste and texture.  The cheese and avocado registered, but the beef was not juicy, nor flavorful.  Their fries were the type with extra starch applied to make them crispy. They were not to our liking.  The six medium sized shrimp were grilled well and had good taste, but were not "blackened" with enough spice, nor exposed to mesquite coals to bring up the special blackened flavor.  They were well prepared without that, but  for $19 we looked forward to more. Finally, the "best" meatloaf, wasn't.  It was overly dense and baked far too long.  It was dry and burnt in part, making the pockmarked surface look like a rock sample from Mars.  The sauce was overly salty.  The potatoes and beans were fine. 

Could be that we came at Johnny Apples the wrong way.  Perhaps, the apps alone with beer was the way to go.  Nice things have been said about their wings.  Regardless, we experienced a less than compelling meal that would deny a  good reason to return.

I really like the imagery Blue Ocean creates in my mind. Cool tropical island daylight. Fresh air. Clean water. Right off the boat fish for filleting into optimal sushi. Who wouldn't want sashimi or exotic rolls made from the best sealife available? Poetic license can be effective in selling a restaurant to consumers, but actual execution is what matters most. 

This location is making a third attempt at Asian kitchen success. Yummy Sushi was here for several years before moving to the College of New Jersey neighborhood. Fame Dish arrived next, claiming to be an Asian fusion house, when in fact it was primarily Chinese with a wave to Thai, Japanese and Viet cuisine. It was gone in a year, because it was more confusion than actual fusion. Now Blue Ocean has taken over with the promise of sushi done right, plus a menu covering a lot of dishes from The Land of the Rising Sun. 

First, it seems that management is Chinese, and that the sushi chef speaks Mandarin. So, sushi culture is not spoken as a first language. Still, the preparation and execution can excel with well trained hands and high quality ingredients. Second, it seems they are following the course of most such houses by duplicating the menu prescribed by graduates of Sushi University - limited high quality fish and lots of rolls with clever names; generic soy sauces, and gloopy ginger salad dressing. No creativity is possible with poor basic ingredients. 

I ordered a spicy Salmon Roll and chicken katsu, to sample two aspects of the menu. The chicken came as a dinner with choice of soup or salad. Two deep fried spring rolls were brought to the table as a complement. Nice touch. The salad was all iceberg with a few carrot shavings. The dressing was that poor quality ginger mash. The lettuce hadn't been fully sliced, so a lot of it was still one piece and difficult to collect with only a pair of chopsticks. The 8 piece roll was okay, but not the freshest. Finally, the katsu was two thin cutlets, breaded and deep fried with a good dipping sauce. Sadly, it was cooked just beyond the point where it was juicy throughout. Liked the crunch, but not enough to want to eat all of it. At $17 it was a pretty big miss. The spring rolls were solid. 

I hope Blue Ocean understands the issues and really wants theirs to be a first class sushi house. They can certainly make it so if they don't accept shortcuts and focus on quality across the board. 

Wishing them insight and excellence.

LUNCH MENU ONLY REVIEW

Peking House on Makefield Road, Yardley (actually, Lower Makefield), Pa., sits in an older strip center that also houses RJ's Bagels and a couple of nail salons.  So, if you want to have some Chinese takeout while having a pedicure this is your special place.  

Otherwise, the grub here is pretty standard fare for Chinese/American joints.  It relies on take away business, with only one table and service for eat ins in the same takeout containers.  They were able to boil water for hot tea, which so many these days just refuse to offer.  It was appreciated.

My lunch special was pork egg foo young, with fried rice and wonton soup.  The soup was the weakest link.  The dumplings were thick skinned and were filled with some meat thing that had little taste.  The broth was likewise, flavorless.  The pancakes were decent, with plenty of veggies and thin strips of pork.  The brown sauce was a bit too cool and had congealed in the plastic container. No Thanks!  The rice was made at some point in the past with a yellow dye  bouillon, but was too hard and past its prime.  

There may be some better things on their menu for dinner, but as this isn't in my neighborhood, I am unlikely to find out.

Aldo's Pizzarama on Bustleton Avenue in far Northeast Philadelphia has been at the same location for a couple of generations, and has the reputation for making the best pie in this part of the city. Perhaps, it has changed hands since those opinions were expressed, but it was not our experience when we stopped in for dinner over the weekend. 

The guys behind the counter, although not busy, seemed unwilling to crack a smile or offer any service beyond taking our order and shouting out when the pizza or steak sandwich was ready, for us to pick up and deliver to ourselves. No silverware, no napkins, no courtesy offered. 

My son liked the steak, but said it was not worth the drive to have it. The pizza looked great with crisped sausage slices and well done crust. The problem was the overuse of cheese out of proportion to the sauce. It was such a heavy layer that the undercarriage could not support the topside. Lifted from the outer edge left the center of the slice on the aluminum pan with its contents sliding off. The work involved in folding the slices allowed us to taste how salty the cheese and red sauce were. Just not a good pizza, despite the decent crust. 

Won't be back.

The key to understanding the Bagel & Bread House on Horsham Road is hidden in plain sight. The shop is quite small, and all you see are wire bins of bagels and a self serve coffee shelf, but not actual "bread" shown for sale. Nary a loaf in sight. 

Why is that? 

Best I can ascertain, at this business they are one and the same. A bagel is bread is true, but by that generalization, so are crackers and pita. Simplistic, but telling. While all bagels are bread, not all bread are bagels. Perhaps, by such gross definition, you don't focus on the doughy fact that you can make bread look like a bagel, but it may not actually be one. To my taste, this is what occurred here. These round wheels are perfect facsimiles of bagels, and look great. Still, by taste and texture they are not bagels. They are bagel-like bread creations that have neither the consistency, nor taste/texture of the real thing. It's not that they are bad, but more a surprising disappointment that upon first bite, reminds of sliced sourdough or rye, more than a properly boiled and baked traditional delicacy. 

So, the best I can conclude is that at this establishment bagel and bread refer to the same thing. Problem is, there are no real crisp skinned, flavorful insides, light or dense, boiled and baked goodies here. Only bread in the form of bagels. 

Some like them, but not worth the trip if real bagels are your preferred destination.

Maybe it was because I was there on a Wednesday evening, and the dining rooms were not crowded, mirroring the condition of the large buffet displays which were likewise limited in choice to few main courses, sides, breads and desserts, but there really wasn't much to enjoy about the dinner options that I had just paid in advance to consume, sight unseen. While $20 might have been reasonable for repeat visits to the buffet tables, that value proposition was shot to shit if the first rule of buffet dining was not accepted by the diner. 

Be prepared to chow down in extremis, or the whole thing is a waste. Healthy dining this is not. 

A half gone tray of meatloaf with choice of light/dark gravy, large pile of fried chicken as the only protein; a few macaroni/cheese elbows, Penni broccoli, mashed, stuffing and was that yams(?) as the heavy carb offerings, along with some nondescript bread; followed by copious amounts of jello, pudding, cookies, cheesecake squares and one last slice of dried out raspberry pie - all amounting to a heavy lugubrious carb centric plate. I neither wanted more after laboring through the first, nor would it have been wise for me to have attempted another helping. 

Beside that, that raspberry pie lacked any berries, but was a purple sweet colloid held in dry tasteless crust, and thus, without redemption. 

I just can't consume like that, nor was I really tempted to do so. But, I learned that my hunger is nothing compared to what the Golden Corral crowd is capable of.  Perhaps that explains why almost everyone there wore elastic waist sweatpants. They knew what they were there for, while I learned the hard way that it doesn't pay for people without that corpus and habitude to so indulge. We should know that the experience will be largely wasted on us. 

Pass the Pepto, please!

Decent chicken salad sandwich, but the place is really dirty. Sat at a small table downstairs in their basement shop. The cracks in the red paint were black with grime and lack of strong cleanser for too long. Same for the floor and back shelves and undercounted storage space. 

Need to do better and care more, even if never inspected by L & I.

I was looking for a place where I could have both a foot massage and get some body work for my aching back. H A Foot Spa on Bridgetown Pike, Feasterville, advertised that combination for a 90 minute session at a reasonable price. Website photos showed a room with large recliners used for leaning back with feet in a bucket of herbed hot water, so it seemed they knew what to do. 

Well, not exactly. 

My private room was well appointed, and the masseuse pleasant, but she wasn't very skilled in Chinese massage. I asked for a strong technique, but she couldn't do it. Little pushing, digging nor probing with hands, elbows nor forearms. Little stretching of my limbs. On the other hand she did use hot rocks on my shoulders and lumbar, and hot towels after oiling my back and legs. It wasn't bad, but more strength as requested would have been better. 

The bigger problem was that I must have misunderstood what they meant by combo foot and body work. Many past experiences provided 30 minutes off the table and in a recliner with foot bath and heavy hands on feet. Disappointed that never happened. In place of a real foot spa exercise, I remained on the table and was given a weak massage for about 20 minutes. A real foot massage is strong, digging and often a little painful. This was far from that. This felt more like going through the motions. 

I will return to my regular foot spa down on Bustleton Avenue next time. They only offer chair massage as part of the hour, but they are expert in what they do.

East China Restaurant in the Giant Shopping Center in Morrisville, Pa., may have been in operation for a long time...and, it shows.  

First impression upon entry is of a large buffet table (empty at night), torn carpet, dim lighting, and a desperate need of a makeover.  The temperature is lower than comfortable as demonstrated by the hostess/owner wearing her coat as she seats and serves.  This may be primarily a take out joint, but the large dining area belays that, and a few of the other reviews reflect dining in experiences.  

My light bite dinner of Wonton Soup (I ordered Hot & Sour Soup, but what the hey...?!), and Fried Dumplings was average.  Chicken Broth with standard yellow dye, thick wonton skins and a meat filling that was lacking taste.  Same for the Dumplings, with the exception of the dipping sauce which I doctored with chili sauce requested for flavor.  

East China feels and looks rundown and in need of a bright facelift.  The owners seem content to do the minimum required to keep the doors open without real concern for customer satisfaction nor comfort.  

There are better Chinese/American houses nearby more deserving of your appetite.

This is strictly a two slice and a Coke review.

Maybe it is just the luck of the draw that I walked into Aquilone's Cucina in the H Mart strip center only a few days after having one of the best Tomato Pies in my life over in Jersey.  Or, maybe it was because that unique experience fostered my desire to duplicate it in a new place.  Regardless, I was hungry and decided to eat something before going shopping in H Mart on an empty stomach. 

Aquilone's is a fairly large joint with room enough for close to 100 people.  The colors are predominantly yellow and brown, and on a rainy day seemed to mirror the overcast darkness all around.  I ordered a slice of regular pizza and one with Italian Sweet Sausage and asked them to be reheated long enough to be well done.  

When they arrived on a large plate (so much nicer than being handed pizza on paper plates), they looked good and heat was rising off of them.  I wasn't provided with utensils, and when I attempted to pick up the first slice, it immediately drooped over from the weight of the cheese and the fact that the center of the crust was not really very hot.  Too, oil dripped off suggesting that the crust was in fact somewhat soggy.  

The taste was fairly good, but it was obvious these pies had been on display for a while, and had lost their life force. The same was true for the Sausage slice.  Quality meat, yet the cheese and sauce needed more refreshing than a turn in the oven could provide. 

Perhaps, I should know better than to go for a late two slice lunch when the available pies have been around too long.  But, I did not want to ask for a new pie to be made, and there are shops that routinely put together new pizzas for the by the slice crowd every few hours so their wares don't lose their verve.  

Nice folks. Good service.  But, these slices were past their prime.

All malls are dinosaurs waiting for extinction. 

Neshaminy is no different.  Aside from the entertainment value of the AMC theaters, there is little to recommend it.  After ruining Main Streets around the world with large parking fields and lots of meaningless choices, they are now suffering the same fate. 

People are "Malled Out!" 

We want something more integrated into our communities; part of our social fabric, not something standing alone and uninvolved.  The next generation will be synthetic villages.  Smaller shopping markets clustered together and surrounded by neighborhoods, schools, parks, hospitals,  employment opportunities, and good roads leading to the rebirthed urban centers.  It is called by many names, New Urbanism, Post-Modern Cities, Back to the Future, etc. But, it is definitely coming. 

There are examples of this next utopian model around the world, and if you find one be sure to investigate.  

I, for one, am excited for the chance to return to a future full of the elements that made earlier societies function efficiently, while adapting the best that technology and science have to offer.

When it comes to coffee there are three main ingredients: 1. the coffee, 2. the water, and 3. the maker.
At Dunkin Donuts the constant is the coffee.  The makers are all trained in the same methods and everything comes packaged for ease of use.  That makes the quality of the water the primary variable. 
For some reason, the coffee at this DD tastes different (in a bad way). It is harsh and leaves a bitter aftertaste.  It must be the water, because the nearest other DD in Lower Makefield near the Hampton Inn does not have this problem, but they are serviced by a different water company.
Elementary, my dear Watson...

Worst pizza so far in my exploration of the tomato pie universe in the Trenton/Hamilton area.  

Although visions of The Godfather played in my head, this is a very different branch of the Corleone family.  This is a tiny shop, with only 4 deuce tables within.  Take out or delivery is the business model here. That would be fine if the product made eating slightly "delivery aged" pie worthwhile.  I ate two plain slices right off a pie out of the oven, but my participation did not match my anticipation of the meal. 

The slices came out on overlapping white paper plates.  I shook dried pepper onto them, made the fold in the crust to aid in pick up, and lifted.  The point immediately sagged as the underlying crust foundation was not firm enough to hold it.  As it flopped back to the plate, an inordinate amount of oil began to flow off the surface and onto the plate and table.  Not a good sign.  The visual was of a lot of cheese with little tomato sauce showing.  My first bites confirmed that this was more like a double cheese pie without much sauce.  The cheese was mildly salty.  The lack of gravy suggested that there would be no subtle basil flavor, which I prefer.  Such was the case.  

After struggling with the chewiness of the excessive cheese, the lack of a balancing rich sauce with proper herbs, and a veritable drizzle of oil from both front and rear of the slices, I already knew this was not going to be my pizza place.  If the straight ahead plain slices could not pass muster, I wasn't going to try anything more complex.  

One nice positive - the zepps (fried dough dusted with powdered sugar) were amazingly good!  A bag of three came free with any purchase.

For some reason, I was sitting in this DD trying to check in on my mobile phone, and was told I was too far away!  I guess that depends on what dimension of reality you are measuring from. Or maybe, this is in one of those GPS warps, where the directions get lost due to cosmic interference. 

Otherwise, nothing special going on here. The coffee is only Okay (bad water?), but I have noticed a deterioration of DD coffee quality at many shops over the past few years. They really need to standardize the water variable, because without good water, the coffee beans can do little. 

My son's basketball team was celebrating the end of their season here last night. The boys seemed happy with the Baskin Robbins, but I saw a dish of strawberry ice cream that was so red, I wondered what red dye farm it had visited before being consumed. 

Loved the company, but will live without their goods in the future.

After exploring the canyons of The Home Depot, we walked out into the cold dark gray sky. We were a little hungry after all the hiking and saw this Burger King on the edge of this shopping zone on Bromley Road. 

The store was nearly empty @ 3:00, and there was no wait to order. Whopper meal and a double cheeseburger from the value menu. Easy. Right? Except, our order taker thought we wanted a second meal when we only wanted the sandwich along with the Whopper meal. Small miscommunication that was fixed with managerial assistance after the register froze. 

The burgers were typical of BK cuisine. Adequate fast food. The Freestyle sodie dispenser was still fun. So many choices at my fingertips. Absent were any condiments on this side of the counter. No ketchup pump. No salt or pepper. No plastic utensils. I'm sure they had their reasons. 

This experience wouldn't have been particularly notable if I hadn't been to another BK two weeks before in Pa (Oxford Valley), where we were literally treated like fast-food royalty, in a shop that even has a fireplace lounge, and a real personal touch.

Spoiled us for future BK visits.

This is a review of Plain Pizza Slices served at lunch.

While the reheat did a good job firming/crisping the crust so that the point held up and provided a firm bite, the remainder of the experience was somewhat of a letdown.  The sauce was on the salty side, while I prefer a sweeter, more basil flavor tone.  The cheese was ample, but without much taste to contribute to overall dining pleasure.  

Two slices and a soft drink came in under $7.00, but the same can be had a several other places for at least a buck less. 

Reviews say that their cheesesteak is the way to go at Venezia, but when the standard tomato pie is so ordinary and uninspired, I would not elect to return to give something else a try.  There are too many better choices in the vicinity. 

Venezia does not make the cut for a quality pizza slice.

Located on what has become a dead end on Mill Creek Road just before reaching the old Delaware Canal, the inn that shares its name with the road feels like it knows that it is now at the end of the trail, and is depressed about it. While prices are downright cheap for food and drink, the house has a dark and dusty aura. It does have its attractions, with pool table and large rectangular bar with a few primarily domestic beer on tap. Too, it is a smokers tavern, and a haven for those who enjoy socializing with ques and tobacco. For me, a non-smoker, the atmosphere was challenging. 

The menu is limited, with cheesesteaks, burgers and a few Italian specialties (meatballs galore). Seeing that, I went with their California Burger and fries to get a sample of what they should do well. Well, my hopes exceeded reality. Looking good on the plate with fresh, soft large bun, the puck itself was 8 ounces of previously frozen ground beef, with little flavor beyond what was provided by the cheese and red onions. My request for a medium finish was returned far closer to well done. The half order of fries was plentiful, but with starchy texture and no crispness. Just a disappointing effort. 

Sitting at the bar, I received pleasant attention from the tender, who was kept busy all night pouring shots, drafts and cracking bottle caps. She moved quickly, and was clearly on top of her game. 

The cigarettes forced me to depart soon after finishing my meal and Michelob Ultra. It is unlikely there is enough there to make a return visit.

If truth in labeling is to have any credibility, then Szechuan East deserves low grades for honesty in the kitchen. While at one time it may have been truly a spicy Chinese hot pot, with red chilies and black peppercorns to adorn their dishes, somewhere along the line it ceased to be that place, and became quite something else.  If I had to guess, I'd surmise it changed ownership a few years ago, with the original Chengdu folks selling out to people from Zhejiang Province (near Shanghai), but continuing the popular name without the intention of maintaining a similar menu.  In truth, there was not a red nor black pepper in the house. Neither was their cumin, or other heat focused spices to impact the other ingredients.  The strongest element in the kitchen was Hunan black bean sauce, which while temperate on the tongue, does not approach the numbness required of a Szechuan wok. 

The chef has his skills, and the platters delivered were okay for the most part, but it was a mighty disappointment when we came desiring a visit with the fire god, but came away with the less satisfying earth and water deities. When you drive 30 minutes to a remote outpost in Northeast Philly, with the expectation of one thing, and end up with something less satisfying, it is hard not to scowl at the misdirection of management. This was only complicated by the further misrepresentation on their website that they had a bar, when in fact, they no longer did.  

Still, we did the best we could.  Lamb Hunan, Chicken & Walnuts, Yeh Yang Shrimp, Veggie Chow Fun and Cold Sesame Noodles.  Each was a large portion, visually appealing, and well made in their own right.  The black bean sauce on the lamb added some mild heat to the tender strips of baabaa.  The Shrimp was mildly crisp on the outside, with an adequate, yet semi-sweet finish. The Chow Fun was well done as it should be coming from a chef that was schooled in such things.  The walnuts were the best part of the chicken dish - nicely crunchy and honey dipped, as expected.  The cold noodles were forgettable, especially when we had been jonzen for DanDan.  

The room itself is old school attractive with red leatherette booths.  The service was also fine. They seemed apologetic that we could not get what we wanted.  

Maybe it doesn't make a difference to some what is really being cooked within.  It is also possible that in this backwater of western civilization, the milder, sweeter dishes are what is desired, and the house is just catering to the majority of their customers.  Still, a little heads up as to what was actually going on would be refreshingly more honest, and allow us to decide whether we are willing to accept their compromises.   

We were not.

This was a first visit to Ponticelli's, and on walking in first impressions were positive. Small dining room a little worn around the edges, but a bucket of charm at the bottom of Haines Road, Levittown, PA. We were taken by the friendly service provided by one of the family of owners/operators, and decided to try their dinners rather than settle for their neon signed pizzas. 

That turned out to be our mistake. 

It began auspiciously with a wonderful bowl of cream of potato soup. It was the final drop, but smooth, chunky, perfectly spiced and as good as grandma used to make. It came along with oven heated buttered Italian roll, and decent side salad with balsamic dressing. Then came the entrees, chicken francaise and veal saltimbuca, both over fettuccine. 

They looked beautiful in their oval platters - nicely pan grilled with white wine lemon reduction glistening and the veal wrapped in prosciutto and sauteed spinach. The skill in the kitchen was obvious and I began to salivate at what we were about to consume. Unfortunately, the kitchen had a very heavy hand with the salt, and our excitement turned to disappointment as the first bite landed on the tongue and recoiled at the harsh taste of excess sodium chloride. 

For the first time in many years we returned the plates to the kitchen hoping it could fix the problem. The same food returned to us minutes later. The pasta had been washed to remove the saline sauce from the noodles. That helped. However, the chicken and veal had not been repaired, and were as inedibly salty as before. We tried a few bites and just couldn't do it. We advised our hostess and she removed the dishes for a second time. When she returned we agreed what we would pay for and what should be removed from the bill. It was fair and I went to the cashier to pay. 

I was saddened when the elder gentleman behind the counter attempted to blame us for the problem rather than simple accept the house mistake. Yet, I understood his instinct to defend his people. No point in arguing. I reminded him that we had not raised our voices and stood before him honorably. These things happen. Best just to move on with apologies and reasonable resolution. 

Strangely, I still liked the place and the family making it run. We might return for the highly regarded pizza, but anything with a sauce in a pan would remain off limits.
This is now Dragon of Newtown with new owners.

If this was just about the ice cream, the stars would be shining bright. The maple walnut, butter pecan and especially the apple pie flavors were very good. Left me wishing for more. 

And, therein lies the problem. The pleasant service person inside the tiny take out window explained that the medium cup held three scoops of ice cream. If it did, I should have asked to see the size of the scoop, because what I received was far less than three standard scoops. Rather, there were at best half scoops of the nutty and quarter scoop of the apple pie. They were in the waxed cup to look like big scoops, but the reality was far less. 

For the $$, there should be no skimping, and if they can't turn a profit without a thumb on the scale, perhaps they need to reevaluate their business model. The slight of hand trick just doesn't make folks want to return no matter how good the creamies are. 

Reading the other reviews, the price was raised several times as being an obstacle to enjoyment. For me, it wasn't the cost, but the weight that was the issue. Perhaps, those amount to the same thing. 

We work hard for the money, and don't want to be short sheeted regardless of how comfortable the bed may be.

Vic Sushi & Thai Cuisine is a small Asian house on Easton Road, Willow Grove. They have a split schedule with lunch until 2:30, when they close for a few hours to prepare for dinner at 5:30. I stopped in before the afternoon closure for a a plate of Thai noodles. 

I asked for lad na with chicken. The dish derives from Laotian/Chinese cultural exchange, with thick rice noodles and heavy brown sauce into which is stir fried carrots, snow peas, onion and egg. It isn't necessarily spicy hot, but can be made that way by adding lemongrass or chili sauce available in Thai kitchens. 

I guess the chef hadn't read the recipe, because what was delivered to me was something different. The noodles weren't thick and chewy, but of medium width and thickness. The sauce more a thin gruel than the heavy, clinging, noodle covering reduction it was intended to be. As a result, I was eating a drippy plate of lighter noodles and veggies, without the enjoyable chew and substantial flavor associated with the traditional dish. I had to request a spoon to deal with it. It wasn't awful, but a far cry from what it was supposed to be. 

First impression of Vic's is that it is really just a sushitorium trying to distinguish itself from the competition by adding a Thai tail to an otherwise Japanese fish. While the sushi may be good, the Bangkok piece really doesn't work well. 

One and done.

One door closes and another door opens. 

We were in Mayfair to check out the Italian food at Emma's Cafe on Frankford Avenue, but when we learned it was booked up on Saturday night we decided to roll with it and pop in to the Aja Asian Fusion Restaurant right next door. The mental gear shift wasn't that difficult. 

It had a big dining room and we were led to a booth against the wall in the middle of the room. It looked to be clean in the dim semi romantic light and our server was pleasantly efficient. Their menu made it clear that Aja was primarily a Chinese house with a cross section of sushi related dishes and a very few Thai choices, like pad thai and two curry options. My concern that it was more confusion than fusion was born out when we ordered the shrimp pad thai (only form it came in) and teriyaki salmon bento box with shumai and California rolls, with choice of miso soup or salad with ginger dressing. 

The noodles were far too sweet and bereft of peanuts to have ever been touched by Thai hands, although there was alot of it on the plate. The grilled salmon was a very small steak, but had the right taste and texture. The miso was fine, but the shumai seemed a frozen, cheaply produced variety and the Cali roll was just okay, tasting mostly of avocado and seaweed. From what we saw at the sushi bar they didn't move enough fish to keep it all daily fresh. There was an awful lot being stored in plastic wrap. 

Unless you're satisfied with generic sushi rolls that can mask the flavor/freshness of the fish, Aja Asian Fusion is better wokking up Chinese dishes for you. Leave the Japanese and Thai cuisine for more talented kitchens. 

Once was enough. 

Will make reservations for Emma's next time.

Coming back to Einstein after a hiatus of more than six months, it was shocking to see the changed conditions all around the shop. I never had strong attraction to their bagels, but the convenience and decent coffee was a sufficient draw to get me there sometimes.

This visit, while the staff was still friendly and helpful, it was impossible not to notice the amount of dirt all around.  The floors, counters, refrigerator, coffee urns, etc., all seemed to have been neglected.  I happened to see the back of a coffee sign sitting on the coffee counter, and it had not been cleaned in a long time. 

These are signs of lax oversight and poor training. Either corrective steps are taken soon, or this EBB will slide into oblivion. 

A downgrade is inevitable.  We have all experienced better than this.

Two Slices and a Drink review only. 

I came in around 3 on Sunday afternoon and asked for their 2 slices and a drink special, which is listed on the board for $4.99.  I requested the plain pizza I saw sitting in the display be served, "well done," so that it was heated enough to remelt the cheese and bring them back to life.  

The pizza arrived hot enough, but also clearly past its prime.  Although the underside was firm and held its load well, it was approaching staleness. There should be a time limit for how long a pie can sit around before it is disposed of and replaced for the next customer.  Too, I am not fond of having my fingers burned from the hot oil dripping out the back of the slice when I fold it over in order to gain a stronger grasp.  

Finally, I was charged $6 and change for the snack, clearly above the listed price.  Perhaps, I was there too late, or it was not available on weekends.  The sign should have so stated if that was so.  

Clean shop. But, I have experienced better pizza by the slice.

Although called Tom's Dim Sum, only a small portion of its menu deals with the small plate culture of China.  The first page offers the expected dumplings, shumai and a few cold options, but the majority of the kitchen deals with traditional big plate possibilities. Further, everything is ordered from the menu, rather than using carts and old ladies to bring all choices to the table for perusal and selection. The lack of a floor show is somewhat disappointing. 

More importantly, the quality of the food was also less than stellar and consistent. We ordered a hot & sour soup, crystal shrimp shumai, pork buns and crab/pork xiao long bao(soup dumplings).

 The soup was fine, with plenty of mushrooms, sprouts and a good vinegar base. The crystals were not. Looked shiny great on the plate, but tasted like they had been boiled in heavily salted water. Hot salty wet shrimp were unpleasant on my tongue, and not what was experienced in other houses. The pork buns were dry as if they had been sitting around for a while, although the ground pork filling was okay. The XLB had a decent broth within, but seemed sweeter than normal. Had to bite their top knots off and drop the table dumpling sauce into it to improve the savory flavor. There are much better soupies available in Chinatown. 

Service was fine, and the dining room was clean.

 Tom's is located on 11th Street under the covered portion created by the shopping mall. As our server explained when we asked, this is not really a dim sum restaurant despite the name. As such, it suffers from an identity crisis inherent in its business model. It offers a glimpse of dim sum without fully committing to the full monty experience.

This rating is strictly in comparison to other 5 Guys Burgers and Fries I have sampled. 

I think this is the 5th or 6th Cinco Hombres for me, and sadly, the worst of the bunch. The shop was practically empty when mi hijo y yo arrived around 6:30 pm on a Monday night.  That seemed peculiar at dinner time.  Nonetheless, we ordered our burgers; son a purist wanting only beef and cheese, and dad a single, no cheese, but with sautéed onions, mushrooms, and jalapeno slices.  We split an order of flies.  

When the brown sack arrived it had the traditional oily blotches.  Unwrapping the aluminum foil packaging, I beheld a semi-crushed orphan baby of a burger, pinched and abused and looking for all the world like it required life support.  Whoever birthed this child needed a slap and handcuffs. But, realizing this was only a metaphor, I ate it after lifting its lid to slide ketchup on its head.  I know; I know. I should have done something. 

It wasn't that they tasted that different then the other sliders from this chain, but that they came to us unloved, and unkempt.  Where was the care, poor child?  

I could not figure out if this was standard for this location, or if we had somehow violated an unwritten rule about how much to order.  Perplexing. 

Apparently, we were not the first to confront this odd phenomenon.  Looking around at all the empty tables clearly articulated that there was a problem.  I had just been too slow to grasp it.

Update 2.18.2014  Stopped in after a long night meet at the Crowne Plaza Hotel down Street Road.  First thing I noticed was that the entire kitchen crew was made up of women.  The second thing I noticed was that although they were busy on the grill, one chef shouted over to us to ask if we both wanted doubles, so she could throw them on while standing there, even before taking our official order.  That was a smart and efficient move.  Third thing was that the burger arrived neatly wrapped in aluminum foil, and when opened, the burger was in excellent condition. Forth thing, it tasted great with sautéed onion and jalapeno slices.  

If something like this happens again, I will have to reevaluate my original impressions and review.  These women had it all over the male crew the first time I was here.  

Gentlemen; get your stuff together!

I stopped in after visiting the Jefferson Heart Institute and in need of sustenance after a fasting test earlier in the morning. This Au Bon Pain is conveniently at the corner of 10th and Chestnut. 

The first thing I saw in the front window was their display of bakery sweets and bagels, and I didn't look much further.  I asked for a Everything Bagel Breakfast Sandwich and Coffee.  The staff was uber friendly and had no problem allowing me to switch from a plain bagel to an Everything Bagel.  I paid, took my receipt, and found a small table in back to wait for my name to be called.  

The light crowd was predominantly hospital workers in the scrubs or wearing ID's around their necks.  Most were doing take out, but a few sat and talked with their associates, or fielded text or phone messages.  The flow was efficiently handled.  In about 5 minutes I had my food.  Reasonable wait.

The sandwich looked good (see photo) and had decent taste.  Its downfall was the texture.  The eggs were microwaved into a soft fluff.  I really prefer them cooked on a grill or in a pan for more flavor and chewability. The bagel while fresh, was likewise without the tougher exterior and softer insides, but was soft through and through.  Obviously, a bagel in name only.  Disappointing.  The meal was adequate, but not engaging.  

I did not try any of their signature French-style breads, but they did look good. The critical piece is always the crustiness and right amount of salt in the dough.  If I find myself near an Au Bon Pain with an urge for bread, I will give them a try.  Otherwise, there are too many other interesting and tasty alternatives to consider ABP a contender for my breakfast short list.

Golden Dawn was a disappointment on several levels. 

First, sitting at the end of the counter it took overly long for someone to slip me a menu and offer me a cup of coffee.  I understand busy, but there were several staff people just walking around with their heads down.

Second, the French Toast I ordered, while thick as advertised, had not soaked long enough in the egg mix, and the center of each slice was dry.  This made for a less than enjoyable experience.  Just glad I went with a short stack.  

Third, although I sat at the counter for at least 30 minutes as I waited and ate, no one came by with a pot of coffee and offered to refill my mug.  Again, servers all around trying their best to avoid eye contact with everybody.  They succeeded in making me feel invisible. 

And, in making me feel an unwanted customer.  

Have it your way. 

Without me.

Single Slice Review

I stopped into Tony's King of Pizza for a light bite after finishing an errand nearby.  The shop is fairly small, cozy and family run. 

I just needed a little something to quell the hunger and get me to dinner a few hours off. A slice of pizza was the way to go, and visiting a new place always excited me. At the counter I saw one regular pie ready for reheating and consumption. I asked for a "well done" slice, and sat at a booth to wait. 

It arrived in the hands of the young woman who had taken my order. Shy smile. A sprinkle of crushed chili pepper, and I was in business. It was as requested, with the extra heat remelting the cheese cover and running off onto the paper plate when I picked it up. Burnt fingers. A small puddle of oil. 

The slice was unmanageable with all the leakage. This pizza just had too much cheese and was out of balance with the tomato sauce, which was lost in all the runny goo. 

We're I to go there again, I would try the cheesesteak, or ask for a tomato pie with more tomato and less cheese.

I have eaten lunch at Char Koon three times over the past two years, but never been there for dinner.  While the restaurant is family run, pleasantly appointed, and has a diverse menu covering Chinese, Thai and Japanese entries, including Sushi, the impression is that it is really a Chinese American joint that offers the other cuisines, but does not do a good job with them.  It all tastes "Chinese" and lacks the distinguishing flavors and uniqueness to be found in places that really understand the national dishes of the countries presented, and employees a kitchen that appreciates how the preparations differ. 

I have tried the Pad Thai, General Tsao's  and other Chicken dishes, Soups, and egg rolls.  They are all decent, but can be found in better form elsewhere.  If you find yourself in Langhorne wanting Asian food, there are few alternatives.  You could do worse, but then again, it would probably be better to go across the parking lot to Brothers for pizza, and save your Asian urges for geographic areas with greater Chinese, Thai, Vietnamese, Japanese, or Korean populations. 

 The prices are very good for lunch ($6.00 - $8.00 for combo lunches including soup, rice and tea), and the quantities are large enough to fill you up.  

It is difficult to get excited by Char Koon. Perhaps, their dinners are better.

Two Slices & and Drink Lunch Review -

While the main Carlucci's Italian Restaurant sits around the bend in this shopping center, the primarily take out pizza joint is to the left of Shop Rite.  It is well appointed with nice enough furniture, although our table rocked so much I had to put my foot on its leg to hold it still.  

The pies are ordered at the cashier/kitchen in the back.  There is a display of many of the pies for inspection.  I am not a fan of this approach as there is not "Sell By" time nor date to alert you how long they have been sitting around.  The more pies; the older they tend to be. 

We ordered well done slices of the Cheesesteak Pizza, Old Fashioned Tomato Pie and Plain.  They were only Okay at best.  The Cheesesteak and T.P. were deep dish style, with light and airy crust, that tasted more like bread with toppings, than true pizza.  The Plain slice was more traditional.  It had a satisfactory taste, but had a leaky oil pan and no gasket.  

This is not a tomato pie house I would return to as the samples tasted were not all that good. Probably better to walk over to the mothership for a full Italian meal.

In a strip center at the bottom of Bristol Road, Bensalem, PA, Taste Café is another of those Chinese/American joints catering to the sweet tooth of the American palette. The place is clean, with six tables for dining in, however, this is primarily a take out operation. Their menu has all the usual suspects from General Tso's to chow mein. My lunch consisted of orange chicken, fried rice and wonton soup. 

In reverse order, the soup was served in a plastic takeout container even though I was eating there. I guess they don't have any bowls, because it seems wasteful and less than hospitable to serve and throw away those containers. Even with recycling, it seems incredibly inefficient. The taste was of a soup that had been in the pot too long, with thick skinned dumplings with little stuffing. 

The main course came on a paper plate with the thinnest white plastic utensils imaginable. They could not cut the chicken without bending to the breaking point, and held little soup. I ended up picking up the soup and drinking it from the container. The chicken had the gloopy sauce thickly covering the deep fried breaded chicken morsels. Not an orange peel in sight, and flavor to match. It also seemed they might have been using old oil, as I developed stomach discomfort minutes after consuming it. The yellow dyed fried rice was okay, but also tasted of aging in the pot. 

Not much going for Taste Café, except the average price for the lunch was under $9 with a bottle of water or soda. 

No need to return.

Yelp should consider having a check off box for reviews that deal with take out/delivery or eat in experiences.  They are so often vastly different, that this information would be helpful.  

***

We decided to pick up a pizza from Uncle Charlie's on a Sunday afternoon after shopping in the area.  We walked in, realized that this was strictly a take away kitchen and decided on a regular pie we could bring home to devour.  Everyone behind the counter was pleasant, and it seemed to be a high school operation for local kids. No problem with that.

Everything smelled great all the way home, but after the 15 minute drive the pizza had lost its edge (quite literally).  The underflooring could not hold the topside weight, so every slice we attempted to lift from the box folded and left parts of the cheese behind, which quickly cooled to room temperature and was not enjoyable to eat.  The taste was no doubt impaired by this process, and though we knew it was still pizza, it really lacked much taste from the sauce and remaining cheese.  It just wasn't as good as eating pizza at its source.  

Uncle Charlie must be aware of this as all they have it take out or delivery.  It really puts them at a disadvantage over restaurants that can have patrons eating there.  Maybe delivery is better if it is timely, but their vehicle holds the food in an insulated bag in the trunk.  Somehow, that image is not very appealing. 

Seem like good folks, but their approach doesn't work for me.

What a difference since my last visit. 

I walked in around 2:45, just in time to catch the final few minutes for their lunch specials. I was the only customer. With my first breath inside I thought that the fish had taken over. The atmosphere smelled of piscean excess, like the air filter hadn't been cleaned in forever. Yes. They were a sushi joint and had two large tanks on the premises, but this was ridiculous. Fresh air, please. 

I should have turned around and walked out, because it got worse from there. I sat down and ordered the sesame chicken, which came with fried rice and egg roll. 

Whereas, last time the food was better than average for a Chinese American house, this time it was far worse. The breading was thicker than the meat within. Primarily cheaper, dark meat chicken was used, and it all was overcooked in deep frying, so that much of the pieces were overly hard, like encased in plaster rather than flour. It stuck in my teeth and tasted of old oil. The fried rice was aging poorly and the eggroll was mostly cabbage and more stale oil. 

Really disappointing after a positive first impression several months ago. They must not being doing well, but without better effort and sense of smell, they won't have long to worry about it.

Nate's Hot Bagels is the most forlorn shop in an exceedingly decrepit commercial center on Grant Avenue in Northeast Philadelphia. The large towering sign atop the storefront is bigger than the interior customer space, which is merely a small lobby big enough to turn around and to look at the bagel bins behind heavy Plexiglas protection. Lord knows, people up to no good can't get enough of these round dough mounds, and will go to dangerous extremes to get them. Business is conducted through a narrow space between the plexi and the locked door leading to what looks like a small bakery.  Cash only. Smallest order: half dozen for $5. Don't like it? Tough. Find another rounder house. 

After I got passed the sense of walking into a 19th Century prison, I noticed the bagels looked pale compared to what I was accustomed to. Under baked? Perhaps, but I was there, and I wasn't going to walk out without a score. There was a buzzer button sitting atop the back of the cash register. I pushed it. It croaked out a notice to a man in back, who came up to take care of my wants. He was friendly enough, but didn't look like a baker. No flour in his hair. No poppy seeds stuck to his hands. 

I asked for three onion and three everything bagels, and he went ahead and fetched them barehanded into a brown paper sack, and threw in a plastic bag for home storage in a refrigerator. My $20 returned the bag and $15 paper money. No taxes to account for here. 

So, I tried an everything bagel when I got home, and had a toasted onion for breakfast this morning. They are denser than I normally like, but no question about freshness and full flavor. Definitely worth the gamble entering this mysterious shop. 

Can't escape the sensation that there are more than bagels going on in Nate's, but as long as their signature products deliver on the promise of a decent bagel (and bialys), I can ignore everything else.

Pho Kitch'n on Ridge Pike, Eagleville, PA, is an Asian fusion restaurant with Vietnamese cuisine taking the lead and Thai/Chinese following close behind. It is in a free standing A frame building, with plenty of parking and nice size dining room. 

I went with the namesake noodle soup with lean round steak and fatty flank. It was a large bowl for $8.95 and the stock was good with interesting and subtle flavors from long simmering, and a large knot of noodles beneath the surface. 

Sadly, the side plate of accessories to add to the pho was disappointing, with withered Thai basil and dessicated lime wedge visible with a quick glance. Delivering them to the table was an act of disrespect and slovenliness that is impossible to dismiss as an oversight. The woman serving me certainly put the plate together in the kitchen, and just didn't give a damn, or worse.

Ironically, the pho itself was pretty good (even without the basil and lime), and would have garnered a higher score but for the passive aggressiveness served with the pho. 

2 Stars

It has been many years since this joint was the Lemon Leaf (at least since 2014, if not earlier). Now, it is a Chinese takeout, with a menu half Chinese and half Thai, although the operation is totally Chinese. The waiting area has two tables if you prefer to eat your fried rice hot and not reheated. But, coming from a disappointment of a prematurely closed White Elephant a few miles away, I was still in the mood for Thai, and took a chance at the now named Asian Thai & Chinese Cuisine. 

If there was a classification for "Dive Chinese Takeout," this would fit that description. Dirty all around and a kitchen that hadn't seen a clean mop or ounce of elbow grease in many a year (but, plenty of other grease abounded). Hunger drove me to suspend better judgement and plunge in with chicken pad thai.

 It arrived in styro packing and thin plastic fork 10 minutes later. Ground peanuts atop a pile of medium width rice noodles, mixed with slivers of a few veggies , slices of white meat bird and light brown sauce. I asked for it spicy, so red chili powder was included, but not any heat from lemongrass. 

The taste was nothing like pad thai, but some Chinese approximation of that dish using Chinese spices as substitutes for the real deal. Edible, but lacking authenticity. Satisfied my hunger, but approaching false advertising. 

No need to return. Just hope White Elephant honors the hours on its door in the future.

Pulled up to this Prince Fried Chicken after work one night last week.  The driveway is not on Olden Avenue, but on the side street next to the adjoining liquor store.  Miss that and you will have a job finding your way back here, especially after dark.

That being said, after trying their breasts and wings I will not likely be going back.  When I arrived home and sat down to eat my purchase, I found the coating to be overcooked and the meat a bit dry.  I had noticed that the chicken was a shade darker than richly golden, but as everything in the bin was the same color, I thought that would not be an issue.  It was, however. 

The pieces were meaty and the prices very inexpensive.  If the chicken itself had been crunchy, spicy and moist, it would have been a big hit. It might have been a bad lot left in the fryer too long, or perhaps suffering freezer burn, but you only get one chance to make a first impression.  

Given the alternative fried chicken shacks all around the area, I will keep searching for the perfect batch.

It has been a while since my last visit to any Ikea, and after spending two plus hours in their Conshohockon maze, I remember why I stopped shopping there.  Their warehouses are enormous, and there is so much stuff to look at that it can be overwhelming. But, the kicker comes when you have had enough browsing, decided not to purchase anything in order to consider the possibilities, and try to leave the premises. 

It is then you realize that you are lost somewhere on the second floor and don't remember how you got to the office furniture area. The signs say the check-out and exit is "that way," but that just leads you through every other department in the hanger, past the cafeteria, down the only flight of stairs, and through a second maze on the first floor. The maps sparsely displayed look like a game of Candyland or Chutes and Ladders, with little dots meandering through every corner of the building. It was at least 10 minutes before I reached the cashiers and saw the exit doors beyond them. Someone with claustrophobia could easily panic before reaching fresh air. 

Yes. I did see some desks, bookcases and lighting that might work well in the new office, but not as much as I had hoped. Prices were good, but I had the definite feeling that I would be settling for things based on limited choices, rather than true love of the furniture. And, by the time I made it out of the warehouse, I had little desire to go back in. 

Make it easier to escape and I would have no problem going back in smaller doses to explore and find what I want. Absent that, why would anyone voluntarily submit themselves to such torture?

VITAMIN/SUPPLEMENT REVIEW ONLY

Visited the Carousel Gardens campus today, thinking Organnons Market might carry the things I needed in their vitamin supplement area. It was my first visit so I looked around the shop. Few customers on a Saturday afternoon, but the produce looked good and the canned goods were limited but interestingly esoteric. Nice selection of coffee, too. 

Yet, they didn't have any of the three things I needed that are fairly standard in most health food stores. The worker was helpful, and apologized for not being able to help me out. No sweat. Drove down to Big Bear and found what I needed. Plus, they were selling Kicking Horse Coffee for $3 less per bag then Organnons. 

Good to have a quality locally focused organic food outlet nearby, but given it's inherent inventory limitations and prices, it won't be a regular stop for our provisions.

It would probably be useful if Yelp separated dining in experiences from those of take out, as the issues are very different.  But, until it does, the combined reviews will continue to skew the results in a negative direction in most circumstances.

So it is for China Aston, a fairly nice small Chinese resto in Aston, Pa., although there is another unique issue that applies only to how this house is managed.  

When we walked in the three of us planned to have one person have dinner because she was hungry before a long drive across the state. The other two of us wanted to sit with her and perhaps have an app or soup because we had eaten before meeting up with her nearby.  We discovered a sign on every table that said their was an $8 minimum to dine in, and a $5 min to take out.  That meant to us that we would not be served unless all of us ordered more than we wanted, or got unnecessary take out to keep them happy.  Inquiring of the owner/manager of our circumstances was met with a blank stare and repetition of the House Rules.  

We didn't have time to look for another place to eat, and although wooden, we did not want to violate their demands.  So, I ordered some Orange Chicken and Pork Dumplings for Take Away, and one dish of Steamed Veggies and Rice for immediate consumption.  This satisfied the dowager, and we just grinned and bore it.  

Turns out the Veggie dish while fresh and presented in a bamboo steamer, was bland and needed augmentation.  No Sesame Oil here, only some form of Chili Sauce.  When I returned home and went after the Chicken and Dumplings, I found very ordinary fare, with a thickish coating on the meat, and goopy mildly hot sauce at the bottom of the container.  The fried Dumplings were adequate, but not really hot enough to appreciate its apex taste and texture.  Everything was just meh.  

The final choice of 2 stars comes from the complete absence of customer concern displayed by the house mother.  Rules were rules, and would not be bent or compromised for any reason.  In truth, this restaurant felt more like a school lunch program run by a cold and uncaring matriarch.  

Maybe that's why the place was practically empty on a Monday evening.  

Regardless, my shadow will not touch its door again.

This franchise recently expanded into this part of the world, and I finally found a convenient moment to check it out this week.  It is an attractive Chinese house; clean, organized and designed equally for eat in or takeout.  Yet, not an Asian in sight to speak to authenticity.

The options are set behind glass shielded steam tables, where the workers allow you to select from the number of different dishes offered, and spoon them onto a heavy cardboard plate with a side of white or fried rice.  As everything is prepared beforehand,  unless you arrive soon after wokking, the food cools and congeals to some extent, detracting from its overall taste and enjoyment. I went for orange chicken and Beijing beef with the fried rice.  Both had a good look with different shades of orange and red amber goopy sauce.

The taste of each was distinct, and I believe that if hot, they would have been a satisfying meal.  Unfortunately, that was not the case. Both were barely above room temperature when I sat down, and although I appreciated the flavor and textural potential, the heat issue really drove down my enjoyment.  I don't know how they can fix this problem. I don't like micro-reheats, and question whether they could successfully throw it back in a wok.  

So, I give them credit for an interesting idea, and a tidy house, but just don't want past prime hanging around food as part of my diet.

Standard CVS drug store and food market in Newtown Borough. To my eyes they all look the same and really have little to offer other than prescription drugs. Everything else is predictable and overpriced. 

I am surprised to see that the floor has industrial carpeting throughout, as it is difficult to clean. In a place frequented by sick people such flooring is not optimized for a healthy environment. I prefer hard surfaces that can be swept and washed often. Maybe this carpet is removable, but the question remains, how often? 

The answer, not often enough.

Perhaps it was just this particular Perkins, but it does seem that this franchise is a poor man's version of the ubiquitous IHOP. It was hard not to notice an immediate disappointment moving from the beautiful menu photos to the presentation on our plates. From proud to defeated, boisterously sensational to meekly fallen, the reality fell far from the mark. 

Not that the french toast platter and quesadillas were without taste, but that they were not nearly as grand as advertised. The brioche thick slices absorbed the egg/sugar/vanilla mix, but not quite enough to overcome its dry core. The crisp bacon was not so, and the deflated quesadillas were so thinly filled as to believe the promised steak was little more than tender shoe leather. 

True, the hall was crowded, the prices quite reasonable and the coffee topped off in a thermos pitcher on the table. Kenny's service was friendly, clever and accommodating, but could not overcome the the tools he was working with. 

Perkins appeared to be an anchor of this Grant Avenue neighborhood in Northeast Philly. It should do something to assure that it does not contribute further to its distress.

Man! 

You guys are so harsh on poor little DD here in Holland. 
The three of you only gave it 1 Star apiece. 
 
The coffee is standard for DD; no better, no worse. 
The staff does seem disorganized and a bit comical how they step over each other and can't remember your order.  
The donuts are never really good at any Dunkin, so nothing new there.  

Yeah, I've had way better than everything on the board here. But, is it as bad as finding a mouse in your donut?  (Thus, the "Eek!") 

I think not.

Paying the check from breakfast on the way out, the owner/cashier ask why we were putting such a small tip on the credit card payment. After a second's hesitation born out of the discomfort of having to express criticism directly, I had to explain that the service we received at the counter from the server assigned to us was very bad. He wanted to know what I meant.

First, I mentioned that the guy sitting next to me was never served his meal and just walked out in hungry frustration. Then, I started on our experience. The milk I requested for my coffee took 20 minutes and a reminder to our waitress after she reappeared from her absence from the floor. Ten more minutes before our Greek Omelets arrived and a few more until she brought me silverware so I could eat. Beyond that, I was never offered a coffee refill, and she got the toast order wrong and had to return to the kitchen to redo it. 

Although pleasant enough, she seemed not to see what was/was not in front of her, and unable to anticipate the sequence of providing and consuming a meal. For example, her response to our counter mate leaving in disgust was that she thought another server had given him his order and that he had eaten it. Yet, it never occurred to her that although she had taken his order, but not brought it out, that asking him about it would be the courteous thing to do; neither did she ever walk by him and realize that there was never any food in front of him - not even when she finally refilled his coffee.  Really inexplicable, and inexcusable. 

It's not that the breakfast was bad. It was actually quite good, but the neglectfulness of this woman had gotten to us so much that we ate feeling miffed. It put a damper on our enjoyment, too, as we watched her continue with this behavior with other customers. By the time we were finished and ready to go we were again confronted by her being AWOL. When she appeared again several minutes later we asked for the check and a container for leftovers. She returned with the former, but forgot the later. We asked another server for that and she reached under the counter right in front of us and handed it over. 

Maybe she was just having a bad day, but she certainly rained on our parade and made breakfast an ordeal. But, at least we ate, which is more than my neighbor could appreciate. 

The owner seemed stunned by the story, and said he would straighten it out. Didn't offer us anything as compensation for our inconvenience, which would have been a good move, but at least he listened and believed.

Before getting on the Pa Turnpike early this morning, I made a short detour onto Horizon Boulevard to get some java and a small bite for breakfast.  When Chik-Fil-A was not yet open, I drove through the take out window at Starbucks next door.  

I liked the convenience and time savings of a drive thru, but it seemed like the order taker was also the barista as well as the short order cook.  So, she looked rather busy, and in need of assistance.  Still, she kept her composure and got everything right.  

As usual, the coffee had a burnt and bitter taste, but the extra milk requested helped to soften the harshness.  I asked for their Sausage, Egg and Cheese Sandwich on a croissant, but was told that all these meals are pre-packaged and microwaved just before sale.  I decided to go with the English Muffin as the only option.  I don't like what microwaves do to eggs and bread, so the meal was at best, average.  Nothing I would want a second time.  

Hopefully, CFA will be open next time I find myself in a similar predicament.

Metro Diner on Street Road has the look of a cafe more than a traditional diner, with only a short counter with spinners overlooking the open kitchen, and a dining room to the other side. It is in a new building it shares with an as yet unleased commercial space. It is not the roadhouse a diner was designed to be. 

Still, the menu looked diner. So, what the heck. I was ready for breakfast, and I was already there, and in the hunt for some good french toast. That they had in abundance, although not just the plain egg bread fried with the hint of vanilla and sugar I was hankering for. But, when I asked the friendly server if it was available, she assured me it was. 

The coffee was strong, hot and free flowing. The main attraction was disappointing. It looked great on the plate, especially after melting some butter and running syrup over it. But, upon cutting and first bite, found its insides to be mushy and cooler than the surface. It wasn't eggy inside as you might expect, but almost watery, like the mix had been diluted to the point where it lacked the hen seed to thicken under heat. It just stayed wet. The flavor was about right, but texture counts, too. 

I suppose I could have given it back to them for another try, but wasn't feeling like making that scene. I ate what I could and took my leave. Just glad I hadn't asked for the heavy hitters on the menu, which would have put a bigger dent in my wallet.

It was probably a mistake that wasn't caught before reaching its final destination, but first impressions were damaging.

Nice cold morning. Quiet breakfast with my son before camping. Sausage, egg & cheese biscuit quite tasty.

I am not really a fan of Chik Fil A.  I don't get the name, nor the advertising. 
The chicken sandwiches do not move me.
The only things I like are the breakfast sandwiches and the shakes, which are rich and creamy.

Jade Asian is a replacement for an earlier Chinese resto at this location. On approach it attempts to position itself as a "Fusion" place offering Chinese, Sushi and Thai cuisine.  While the space is clean and bright with a large HDTV on the wall playing NFL games on Sunday evening, and the servers are friendly and courteous, the reality is that this is primarily a Chinese restaurant that doesn't have a Japanese nor Thai chef to handle that end of the menu spectrum.  

While I saw someone working the Sushi Bar who seemed to know what he was doing, it was obvious after ordering Tom Yum Soup (Vegetables) and Pad Se Yo Noodles (Chicken), that they have a ways to go before they should present themselves as offering a real Thai alternative.  

The Soup was appropriately tart, but the Vegetables seem to have been thrown into the pot at the last minute.  While plentiful, they were large pieces that had not absorbed the flavor of the broth from slow simmering.  It just did not hang together as a true Tom Yum would.  I asked for a heavy spice infusion on my Pad Se Yo, but what I got was not a Thai dish at all.  It was Chinese Chicken Chow Fun, complete with the mild Cantonese brown sauce traditional to that dish.  When I asked for additional hot sauce to bring some of the taste I desired, I received only Sriracha in a small dish, but not any Hot Chili Oil, Sesame Oil or even a Curry Powder shaker to doctor it the right way.  

For Chow Fun it wasn't bad, but for Pad Se Yo it was a major disappointment.  

Jade Asian is really more about ConFusion, than Fusion.  For me, it is not worth a return visit as there are much better Thai places in the area.  While I can't comment on the sushi, I am left to believe it likely suffers from the same inauthenticity.

I am not a Star$$$ fan. 

I love coffee that tastes good at its base and does not require extra processing (read, latte, capp, etc.) to make it palatable.  So, it is always somewhat surprising to see these little coffee caves sprout up in supermarkets and box stores and do moderately well.  I admit to having been a happy stockholder for a while, but that did not change my opinion of the underlying product.  

So, I was skeptical when I walked into Target a few years ago, and several times since, to see this outpost hanging its shingle within.  It is still there, but seems to be scraping along with only one person running the operation.  Some people like to sip java as they push their shopping carts around the store.  A few actually stop in only for the coffee and depart.  

It would be great if there were more coffee alternatives around here.  Until then, this place and the competing Dunkin Donuts and diners of the world will duke it out for my coffee dollar.

Full disclosure - I am not a Walmart fan, nor do I enter their warehouse-sized stores very often.  Given the alternatives available for discount shopping, the guys from Arkansas are on the bottom of my list. 

Still, when I needed to pick up a quick pair of glasses to replace the expensive ones my stepson lost somewhere, Walmart was the place to go, as their vision centers offer inexpensive prescription glasses and relatively fast turn around time.  In fact, we walked in shortly before they were to close their in house nook, and were taken care of promptly by one of the white coat people.  We were able to shop for frames, take eye measurements, and pay for the pair in about 20 minutes.  Lens to be ground and framed within a week.  Under $100, compared to the boutique price the first time around when I was willing to be generous, thinking the glasses would not be misplaced within a month of purchase.  My bad! 

While in the store we walked over to the electronics department to check out phone chargers (another lost item by stepson), plus another for the office.  Found the prices to be about the same as online, but surprisingly few options for our Apple and Motorola mobiles. There was only one sales associate in the department, and she was helping another customer find something, while a queue formed at her register.  We were not the only customers to decide not to wait.  

I felt a little unclean and hypocritical spending money in Walmart, but this was a semi-emergency.  To be fair, the vision center handled us well, and seemed dedicated to customer service.

If you are a Spaetzle lover, Barbara's Hungarian Restaurant is your Nirvana.  Ask for a side of the East European doughy pasta, and it will arrive covering the entire plate. To its credit, it is pretty good, especially with the sour cream mixed into it.  

The rest of our meals were not up to its signature dish.  We ordered the Mushroom Stew and Breaded Chicken Cutlet (Schnitzel).  The Mushrooms were canned, and the sauce the same weak reddish liquid that was at the bottom of the chicken dish.  Little imagination. Less taste.
 
Canned mushrooms? Really? 

The Chicken Breast was large, thick and nicely breaded.  It was juicy, and would have been the winner but for the saltiness of the coating.  It was obvious no one had bothered to taste the ingredients and preparations in the kitchen.  

Both dishes came with Spaetzle overload.  The Mushroom Stew was really canned shrooms and spaetzle, with nothing else to make it a "stew."  The chicken lay naked on another thick bed of the same thing.  Nary a garnish or side dish to break the monotony.  It must have been obvious, because we were offered a Cucumber Salad by Barbara when she saw how forlorn our meals appeared.  That salad was the best part of the meal, although it would have been nice to know we were being charged $5 for that small bowl with sweet vinegar and thin sliced cukes.  

Maybe, they were having a bad night, but based on our experience I wouldn't consider going back.  There are far better East European restaurants in the area where the cuisine really shines.

Two Slices & and Drink Review Only - 

The image in mind from the name was of an Italian shop anchored by the culture and cuisine of the eastern shore of the boot.  Not quite.  In fact, the reference is to the other side of the Adriatic Sea.  

I went in for a quick dinner of their pizza.  The dining room was attractive with marble walls and tile floors.  The counter zone housed the ovens and the shelved display of pizzas already made and waiting for reheating. Wanting to sample the wares, I asked for one regular and another sausage.  They were about the largest slices of pizza I had ever seen, and in truth, one would have been enough.  Eyes bigger than stomach, I retreated to a table to await delivery.  All the while, the phone rang off the hook with take out orders, which were all fielded smoothly by the young woman dealing with this.  She asked good questions, and kept her poise and easy manner.  

There is always a risk in consuming pie that has been sitting around for a while.  Sometimes, even when requesting "well done," it is not left in the oven long enough to revive the underlying taste of the pizza when first constructed, or they have been out so long that no amount of fire resuscitation will bring them back to life.  Such was the case this night.  The copious cheese topside was hot, but not enough to allow the flavor to come to the fore.  The undercarriage dough was amply scorched, and better than what was supported above.  Just not much life there.  The sausage triangle was similar.
