The pellet shaped meat was cooler than the cheese around it, and lacked any real taste at all.  It left me wondering where they found this sausage vendor, because it neither looked, nor tasted, Italian.  

No doubt Adriatic Pizza is a popular spot for fresh pies and platters judging from the orders calling in, and the other reviews.  It is just not a good place for reheat jobs, even with an incredible price of under $5. for everything.

Old Friends Pizza, way down on Hulmeville Road, Bensalem, PA, has just enough table space for a few old friends to join you to mange Italiano. Four tables. Four chairs per. If you want to invite more than 16, well, that just can't happen. 

You also need to be sure the air conditioning is working, otherwise the party will be a little uncomfortable dealing with the heat and humidity, as I was. 

Not in the mood for pizza, I ordered an eggplant parmijiana sandwich on torpedo roll. I passed on the suggestion to add fries to that. Saw no need for the extra calories. I found a chair in the empty dining room and watched the Thursday afternoon rain through the storefront window. 

One of the kitchen guys served my lunch on ceramic plate. So much better than paper. It was a large production, with thick slices of breaded and browned melanzone, layered with chunky red sauce and overlain with melted provolone by a turn in the oven. It was really too zoftig to pick up by hand and jam into my mouth. So, I asked for knife and fork - the table tools associated with proper dining. In reply, I was handed two thin plastic utensils. 

They both failed the strength test, as they bowed and cracked attempting to cut through the sammy. The knife gave up from the density of the bread, and snapped in half. I decided to eat the eggplant, sauce and cheese with the fork used to pull things apart before spearing. Not the funnest way to go. 

The taste was pretty good, but needed more sauce and less oil. It would also have benefited from thinner slicing and hotter pan to sear the copious coating, rather than the oil being absorbed into it. 

This was not Old Friends finest hour. Pizza would have been a better way to go.

This site attempts to do too many things. 

In addition to housing a Dunkin' Donuts, it is also a Getty Gas Station, mini-deli, and lottery dispenser.  As a result, the place feels disorganized like it has a bad case of Attention Deficit Disorder.  Parking is limited and a bit dangerous with all the different uses bringing vehicles in from all directions.  

The DD coffee is average.  The Bagel with Lite Veggie spread was toasted automatically, although I prefer it not, causing a cream cheese melt and a small mess in my car.  The taste was decent for a mass produced bakery product, but these rounders will never be mistaken for quality bagels.  

It will do when time is very short and an injection of caffeine and a few calories are needed to survive through the first court appearance of the morning. Other than that, this is not a shop I would select for a morning munch nor java stop.

This was one of the more bizarre shops I have visited in the USA.  Clearly a take out dive with only one table with 5 chairs for those unlucky enough to need to eat in house (Moi), these folks clearly make food as a secondary enterprise to the antique business they run in the same space.  I was able to peruse some attractive Chinese and Western vases and curios while waiting for my meal to reach me in its polystyrene container.  Not an expert, but having spent enough time in China to know how these things are done, most of what I saw were copies of older pieces.  Of course, they insist they are the original Ming Dynasty pots, but no way they would leave them out in the open of a tiny resto if that were so.  The real McCoy's are under lock and key because of their large valuations.  

Anyway, I know they do better with the pottery than the slop served, because the old man drove up in a Hummer full of more ceramics as I walked back to my car.  Which leads me back to the food.  I don't mind that there was no washing of hands between touching old pots and cooking pots.  I didn't mind that the menu I was forced to look at was smeared with sauce and whatever, rather than thrown away before I arrived.  I don't even mind that there was no air conditioning and the door was left wide open to allow me the pleasure of sharing my meal with flies.  

But, I did mind that the Chicken had been frozen too long and lost its tenderness, and that the Fried Rice was a copper color from being dyed by the bouillon it had been cooked in yesterday.  What surprised me in all this were the actual veggies that found their way into the dish.  Not just Broccoli, but Water Chestnuts, Fresh Mushrooms, Carrots, Snap Peas and even Black Fungus (the good stuff) were all mixed in.  I didn't expect to see that in an otherwise lackluster presentation in styro.   No. Someone around there knew something about cooking, and took the time to get authentic ingredients for this slovenly meal.  The General's sauce was also near amazing, because it actually had the Hot/Sweet balance generally considered the proper taste for this dish.  

Why they were able to develop the right sauce with the high end veggies, while throwing in old Chicken and rerun rice, is beyond me.  But, in retrospect it was no more unusual than the store itself.  

I don't think I'll be back to Ying Hui unless I am looking for an attractive ersatz vase for a gift for someone I don't care too much about.

PS. Don't be too impressed with that Top 100 Award.  Whether than is legit or not, it certainly wasn't given for this operation.  Those awards are for sale on the internet.

China Chef in the Richboro Shopping Center is an average Chinese/American house that caters mostly to the take away crowd.  There are a half dozen or so tables, but the atmosphere is rather dreary, and not conducive to a comfortable meal.  The management is friendly and helpful.

My recent experience had me opening my bag of goodies at home for a first look.  My order of Fried Dumplings was not the crisp, browned dough pocket I envisioned, but rather a soggy, fried only on one side, unattractive package.  I had to refry them to bring them back to life. I also remixed the dipping sauce to add more heat as the one that came with the dumplings was mostly vinegar with little taste of ginger or chili pepper.  

The Egg Foo Young was thick and loaded with veggies, pork and egg, but left too long in the wok.  The surface was too dark brown, but the taste wasn't as bad as the look. The Brown Sauce was good, and there was more than needed to cover the 3 pancakes.  

Orange Chicken was plentiful; enough for at least 3 helpings.  The breading was a bit soggy; again not the crunch I was looking for.  The taste was about right, but the texture was off in the same way the dumplings were.  

Overall, this was an average meal with too many shortcomings to have China Chef join my short list of China joints recommended for a fast meal.  

The search continues.

Misleading advertising is a turn off. 

This Original Dominick's Pizza joint on W. Trenton Avenue in Morrisville, Pa., has no relationship with the true "Original Dominick's" other than they owned/operated this restaurant until a few years ago when it was sold to the current people.  I guess the contract didn't require that the brand be protected, or perhaps the price included continuing the signage.  Regardless, if you click on the website listed here there is a straight up disclaimer that this store is not part of the family.  

And, they really should care about their image, as the pizza and tomato pie prepared here are a few steps down from what you can eat at the Richboro and Washington Crossing outlets.  The Brooklyn and Tomato Pie slices I consumed the other evening were okay, but lacked the flavor of quality sauce and cheese.  Even the dough was less appealing.  

Some may think that hanging a sign on the side of the building exclaiming new management is enough to alert the public that everything within had changed, but the name.  But, truth in advertising (even passive signs left over from the old regime) is important, and tells a lot about what is happening now.  

Perhaps, that explains why the house is nearly empty whenever I drive by.  I won't be going back.

Another variation of the endless fastfood burger joints, this one a Wendy's.  

Plenty of parking around the free standing building, but designed to have the only entrance door right near the drive through line.  Dangerous. Why not have them separated on opposite sides of the building to protect folks going in?  

The dining room was empty at 2:30 in the afternoon.  Clean.  Plenty of tables, with seats all facing north and south.  I was looking for something easy for a late lunch and opted for the 4 for $4.  Fine print - you get a single sandwich of your choice, and must accept the 4 count chicken tenders, flies and a drink.  Want 2 burgers?  Tough luck. That's not how this deal is played.  Ridiculous!

Can't remember what I ate, other than it was hot and forgettable.  The tenders were average, and the French fries pretty good.  Large lemonade washdown.  Guess that's the point.  When the fries are the best part of the meal, there is a serious creativity problem at Chez Wendy.

Ho - hum.

Miller's Ale House is a chain out of Florida with outlets from Nevada/Arizona, to right here in River City.  It sits on Rt. 1 (Southbound side) in Langhorne right up against Oxford Valley Mall.  It is easy to miss.  

Perhaps, it should be.  It is basically a sports bar with televisions abounding, large beer offerings (the usual suspects in national brands, plus some better known smaller breweries.  The food is what we have come to expect from similar houses - lots of fried food, burgers, wings, salads, even an occasional lobster has been seen sitting at the bar.  It is all basically okay, but nothing worth going back for a second time, unless you find the bartenders or waitresses to your liking (then you are not going for the food). 

Given a choice, I prefer the genuine local establishments, which in Newtown are The Clubhouse, Isaac's, Friends, and even The Green Parrot for either a comfortable place to drink and smooze, or watch the Olympics.  We all know our favorite dives.  

Miller's is an adequate alternative, but never feels like home.

When it comes to old line fast food burgers like Wendy's, everything has to be graded on a curve. No one gets an "A," so to make everyone look better, the best of the worst gets the highest grade and all others climb a few steps. Yes. They are better than they used to be. But, no. They are not as good as the weakest of the newer fast casual competitors. 

So, very late from court, and famished, I saw the polkadot dress and drove in.  My Doublestack came preloaded with ketchup, mustard, pickle, red onion and lettuce. When undressed, the bun looked as it had been compressed in wrapping.  The taste was reminiscent of a burger I used to know, but the saltiness detracted from the possibility of true enjoyment. 

The fries were fine. 

This "4 for 4" deal comes with mandatory processed chicken pieces (scrappled chicken), that was oily and nearly inedible. One was enough. They must have manufactured a billion of them, and be trying to get rid of them 4 at a time through this marketing gimmick. Bad idea. Better just to throw them away, and make it a "3 for 3" special. 

The service was decent. The folks behind the counter were doing their best to keep everyone moving forward. This small store had plenty of seats and parking, so there's that.

Kam Buffet sits deep in the heart of Trenton off Clinton Avenue.  It is a fairly large space and seems to have an active lunch trade.  Service is minimal as in most buffets, with the two women in black directing seating and delivering drinks.  They are friendly enough.

The food spread is a combination of hybrid Chinese American, Latin and variations of fried chicken for everyone.  I sampled a cross section of their offerings, including, General's Chicken, Sesame Chicken, Egg Foo Young, String Beans, Pepper Beef, Boneless BBQ Ribs, and Dumplings.  All were average to below, and some were cool from too much time out of the sun.  Edible fare, but far from inspiring.  

The biggest problem is price.  When such low quality victuals cost $10, there is something wrong with the proposition.  Even Flaming Grill out on White Horse offers much more for substantially less.  And, they use bigger plates without the notice everywhere that if you leave food on your plate there will be a 15% extra charge for waste. Plus, an extra buck for hot tea!  Not a fan of buffet police. 

Hard to recommend Kam unless you are in the immediate area without means of getting to another Chez Chinois.  Almost every China shop around here has lunch specials for $6 to $8, where the quality is better, and the portions ample.  

Kam Buffet. Once was enough.

City Market on Main Street, Lambertville, NJ, has all the charm of this river city, with a 1910 look and feel. High tin type ceiling, large blackboard menu, wooden counter for eating in back, and a window bar in front for sipping coffee. It is definitely a place you feel comfortable and timeless. 

They are open for breakfast, and I was there to sample it. I asked the friendly server what they were about, and she replied that breakfast sandwiches were one of their claims to fame. Okay. Let's do a sausage, egg and cheese on Kaiser roll, please. I settled in with a mug of joe and waited for delivery. It arrived minutes later on a real plate, cut in half, and meekly smiling at me. 

It wasn't all that good. Frozen sausage patty, single fried egg a little too dry, and melted white American cheese, on a tasteless, industrial strength roll that looked to have been crushed in transport. Not much effort, nor creativity put into it. Average at best. Not at all what I expected from a Lambertville institution, where the city itself is all about surpassing culinary expectations. 

With all that atmosphere, City Market could and should have been so much more than a boring, unimaginative sandwich.

BREAKFAST REVIEW ONLY

Peter's Pizza & Deli is on the bottom floor of the corner highrise apartment building at Cooper & Market Streets, Trenton, NJ, right across the streets from the Hughes Justice Complex and the Mercer County Criminal Courts.  As "Location is Everything," these guys should have it made.  In fact, they do a good business for breakfast and lunch during the workweek.  I stopped in for a late brekkie earlier this week.  

The shop was empty but for me around 11.  It is small with only a few tables.  Ordering is done at the counter, where you return to pick up your meal.  I went with a sausage, egg and cheese sandwich on a Kaiser roll, plus coffee.  I watched as the eggs were cooked in the microwave (don't like what this process does to eggs), and the sausage done the same way. The cheese was added at the end and melted by the heat of the other ingredients.  The roll came out of a plastic bag.

I can't say that I really enjoyed this sandwich.  The roll was soft; without much flavor and little texture.  The eggs were fluffy, but with almost no taste.  The sausage was okay, but would have really come to life if grilled on steel.  The coffee was decent.  

Looking around, the pizzas on display looked better than the sandwich I was eating.  I might return to check out a few slices, but the breakfast sandwich was one and done.

I must confess.  I don't like malls. They seem dinosaurs in the 21st Century. 

Perhaps, part of the problem are the anchor tenants; those big department stores that try to be all things to all people, and end up being quite the opposite - offering a sad retail experience that feels lifeless.  So it was when I decided to go to Sears to purchase a replacement for my dearly departed 12 year old Hoover canister. I knew I was risking a bout of depression, but throughout my life Sears was the place where appliances were plentiful.  My grandfather shopped there for refrigerators and washing machines with me in tow, and I would continue the custom with my son. 

Not much to report beyond the fact that our saleswoman was knowledgeable and honest enough to point me in the right direction even when the price was lower.  Ended up with a Hoover Whirlwind in light blue. Good price.  

After putting it together at home, and running it in the family room and a bedroom, I can candidly say that it sucks.

That is a good thing.

Fu Wah (Happy Children) is a small Chinese shop in an old strip center on Olden Avenue Extension, Ewing, NJ. It has the advantage of 8 booths/tables for the eat in crowd, in addition to a brisk take out business. The whole family pitches in during summer. Mom took my order at the front counter. Dad woked it up in the kitchen, and young son served me with a spirited, "Enjoy your lunch."

I would have if the hot and sour soup did not have a large lump of pork fat below the surface, and the sesame chicken wasn't all dark meat with little sauce to stir into the yellow dyed fried rice. 

Get the picture? Not the greatest effort by these happy children.

Was a time Dunkin Donuts was about the best coffee/cake sweets house in the nation because of their consistency. No matter where your caffeine bug bit, there was a DD nearby that could be counted on to offer java and fried dough that was similar from place to place. 

Maybe it's because there are so many coffee houses and high quality roast cafes around these days, but it has been a long while since I truly enjoyed a cuppa joe from Dunkin. Could be the quality of water has declined, or that the beans have suffered from lax quality control or increased competition from all the new java outlets, but even the sweet dough lacks the enjoyability of the old days. 

Hence, I was not surprised when I stopped in to this DD/Baskin Robbins joint to give me a boost the other night, and the small coffee and sour cream rounder were both hopelessly ordinary and lacking in life energy. In a word, they sucked. 

Saving grace? The shop was large and had ample seating. The people working there were pleasant and engaged well with customers. 

Ho Hum.

It's one thing to be almost out of donuts late on a Saturday night, quite another to leave the shop like it was hit by a cyclone. 

There were very few choice by the time we arrived around 8:00 p.m., but enough for our limited sweet tooth and caffeine needs. I grabbed the last toasted coconut, and my sidekick the double chocolate. It was difficult to see what was in the bins because the paper liners were pulled out far enough to block the view, but not removed all together. The same was true around the trash receptacle, where many of the used napkins were scattered around, and the thin waxy sheets used to pick up and bag the donuts were crumpled and tossed haphazardly on the floor and counter. 

Dude in the sloppy outfit and bedraggled white apron seemed to be working alone. Tidiness had gotten away from him, but he did have time to talk on his mobile, and with a bud who was hanging out at a corner hightop. 

Dunkin or DD, there are certain basic requirements for doing the job correctly, and keeping the joint clean is one of them. He must have skipped that class. Made Steve's Prince of Steaks right next door look like a shining palace by comparison. 

Oh, yeah... The donuts and coffee were fine.

Bonnet Lane Family Restaurant is a long standing urban diner on Old York Road, Abington, PA. The space is separated into two rooms; a dining room and another with counter service and a few booths. I chose a spinner at the counter nearest the kitchen swinging door where I could see the work area within when the door opened. Service was provided by a crew of dear ladies who addressed me as, "Dear," throughout my stay. Lovely, efficient and culturally affected. I didn't mind as long as they filled my coffee mug as needed. 

Their menu was most the usual suspects, with daily specials on a separate A-frame in thick plastic on the counter and tables. I went with the Greek Omelette, with the home fries inside the egg shell (That's just the way I like it.) Rye toast finished the platter. 

Loved the way all the flavors ran together, with the feta cheese offering the sharpest retort and the potatoes the most texture. The tomato, onion and spinach nicely occupied the middle ground between these two edges, while the crisp rye complimented the eggs with its mild savoriness. 

I was in a groove with the meal feeling content and nourished. As I sat finishing my coffee, the kitchen door swung open and I saw two kitchen people prepping food without gloves. I didn't know if this was standard practice or just a solitary slip of their more rigorous cleanliness routine, but in the Age of Coronavirus such oversight is not just unacceptable, it's downright dangerous. 

Please guys, caution and public health requires constant vigilance.

Minus 1 Star for unsanitary conditions.

Sulimay's Restaurant down on lower Girard Avenue, Philadelphia, is another of the many neighborhood corner luncheonettes that help define the incredible communities they help anchor. Fishtown has plenty of them, full of local charm and generally excellent grub. We have breakfasted at many of them and looked forward to checking out Sulimay's. 

Walking in, the space was larger/deeper than expected, with nice counter up front and substantial dining room with booths and tables back to the kitchen and restrooms. It was clean and bright with interesting antiques and curios hanging on the walls. We were escorted to the last booth in back where the crash and din of the busy kitchen was easily and entertainingly heard. Our server promptly brought a carafe of coffee and side of milk for me, more than enough for the entire meal. 

I was curious about the PBC (Philadelphia Brewing Company) Kinsinger corned beef hash, which came with 2 eggs, hash browns and toast. What effect did beer have on it? Soon found out. DT had a simple scrambled eggs, house made sausage, hash browns and toast. 

The beer added a touch of savory to the well ground corned beef hash, while the over easy eggs mixed well to moisten the somewhat dry hash. Unfortunately, the potatoes on both plates were on the grill too long and were blackened carbon, although hidden from view by placing it face down at the bottom of the food pile. It was obvious that the cook saw it, as he had to fold them over to show only the unburned side. First bite told the bitter truth. The rest was left uneaten. The sausage was also grilled to excess and not enjoyable to eat. 

We considered returning everything for a second try, but didn't see our server and given how busy it was, and our schedule, we decided to eat what we could and move on for the rest of our day. 

Had there been more quality control and perhaps more caring in what was exiting the kitchen these plates would not have gone out the door. They did, and gave us a poor first impression. Too bad, because Sulimay's has alot going for it otherwise.

Round sugar cakes.

Sweeter than they should be, but fresh baked white cake base is tender and moist at least for a few hours. Many choices for dipped toppings in pretty colors, but all taste more or less the same. Really a confectionery more than a bakery. 

To be avoided if sugar is a health issue for you. Best suited for kids whining for a candy fix, and other folks cheating on their diets. 

Their Covid protocol should be improved a bit, because they allow you to come in to order and then wait outside for a staff person to bring your order out to you in 10 or more minutes. In hot or cold weather it gets a bit uncomfortable. Perhaps, a few folding chairs set up in the shade would alleviate the problem;  outdoor umbrellas, if necessary. 

If you are into Ducks, don't forget your insulin.

Well, maybe that's just marketing. 

Teddy says that the first ingredient in their recipe for success is quality. If that's the case, then corn syrup is really good for you, because that's the first ingredient in the ersatz breakfast syrup served with pancakes and french toast. We all know that the opposite is true, and that such sweeteners should be eliminated from your diet as much as possible. The same is true for butter. Monosaturated fats should be kept to a minimum, yet Teddy served a paper cup with a soft yellow substance in it, rather than real pats of individually wrapped butter. 

Yes. I confess I ate my breakfast, although with less spread and sweet liquids, because I didn't want to be that guy, but decided before my first bite that Teddy would be a one time thing. 

I ordered a short stack when told the french toast was thick. Turned out that it really wasn't so thick, but I didn't mind putting less of the bad stuff in my body. It doesn't pay to describe the taste and texture of the meal, because it doesn't matter - it was based on artificial ingredients anyway. 

The coffee was okay, and I was given real milk when I requested it. So, there's that. It also may explain why the roadhouse was almost empty when I walked in.

Maido! has seen better days.

The "Marketplace of Japan," was our destination after an hour drive from Bucks. We were looking for quality Japanese noodles, ceramic bowls and vinegar unavailable at the Asian supermarket where we normally shop. To our surprise and disappointment there was little of anything on the shelves, and it looked like their inventory had not been replenished in weeks or longer. Same was true of fresh produce, where most bins were bare. What was going on here?!

They literally had nothing we came for. So, we decided to make lemonade from this sour experience, and went over to their restaurant operation in the same space and ordered a few things at the cashier before sitting on stools at a high eating counter facing onto Lancaster Avenue. The Karaage (fried chicken) and Okonomiyaki (veggie omelet) were prepared in their open kitchen and I picked them up when the buzzer alerted me everything was ready. 

The chicken was deep fried from frozen plastic bag. It was not crisp, nor crunchy, but quite oily. The taste of the Karaage powder was there, but the combo of white and dark pieces left much to be desired. They need to improve the quality of those prefab chicken tenders. The Okonomiyaki was better with cabbage, scallion, pickled ginger, yam, bonito and a decent sauce, but the veggie option had little taste despite the ingredients. We finished about half and took the rest home. Its fate has not been determined. At $28+ with two tea bags and hot water, we expected better. 

Not sure what the future holds for Maido!, but its continued presence in Ardmore does not appear assured.

I just encountered a relatively unpleasant experience with Town & Country, but as the facts are uncertain, I can only fairly address the circumstances and attitudes confronted by this event.

Recently I had a sports coat's lining repaired there.  When I returned to pick it up, the work was done well, but there was an ink stain on the front of the coat that had not been present when I brought it in.  I brought it back to inquire about it, and of course they denied causing it, and further could not fix it.  So, bye-bye jacket. 

It is possible that there was a pen in a pocket somewhere when I brought it to them, and that the pen leaked while in their possession.  I cannot dispute that.  However, why wasn't this problem pointed out to me when I picked it up and paid the cost of the repair?  It was quite obvious when I finally took it out of the plastic to wear it.  Regardless of the time the leak occurred (before, during  or after the repair), it was certainly there when they finished their work.  

It would have been more honorable to point this out to me, rather than have me find it once at home.  I am a reasonable guy, and I recognize the ownership of the ink and time of leakage is in doubt.  Still, it was visible to me, and likely visible to them before the transaction was completed.  But, rather than be upfront about it, and explain it was not their fault and only saw the stain at the conclusion of their work, they chose to not inform me, and make me return to them to talk about it.  And, of course, they were defensive and unwilling to see any way they could have handled it differently.  

Not a good business move, as I cannot continue to use their services in good conscience, and I am writing this review to warn off other people who might encounter a problem in the future.  These seem to be nice people, but a bit shortsighted.  All they had to do was deal with me directly, and as if they were sorry this happened even without any admission of responsibility, and I would have been unhappy, but satisfied with their deportment.  As it was, they failed on the human interaction scale, and lost a customer.

The price was great, but the bagel was way below average. 

There was no differentiation between the crust and the meat of the bagel.  Just tasted like decent bread, but without any zest from a firm to crunchy crust, nor air pockets within to make the innards light and airy.  Clearly, RJ's has lost the recipe and won't admit it. 

I appreciated the extra cheese in the sandwich and the coffee club pricing that brought my breakfast in at a skinny $3.  But, still, if it doesn't provide the bagel experience, what am I paying for?  

New York Bagel around the corner on Parkway is a much better bagel option.

Like most of us, Crowne Plaza Philadelphia-Bucks County looked better when it was younger.  What was once smooth, soft and supple, becomes lined, cracked and brittle.  This hotel is no different. 

While it is still capable of putting heads on beds as it did 20 years ago, it no longer looks the part of a beauty queen.  The hair is streaked gray, the laugh lines more pronounced, and the plumbing often in need of repair.  Feel too hot?  Too cold?  

Join the club.

While the drive thru moved well, the actual meal was not worth the wait. 

It had been a while since I was this hungry and rushed enough to consider a BK stop.  This was one of those rare afternoons where I would eat at my desk. 

The Mushroom Swiss Burger was a tasteless and textureless mush.  No wonder you can get 2 for $5.  They want to get rid of them. And, what about the Strawberry Lemonade?  The medium was about a half gallon of overly sweet, strawberry syruped, lemon wash ice water.  

The condensation puddle on my desk slowly spread as I wondered what had possessed me to go for this meal.  Hunger makes for some bad choices.

When you hang a sign touting one of your special offerings, you really have to deliver the goods. When you don't do so it just compounds the failure. 

As we approached Marhaba on foot at the bottom of Mt. Hope Street, Lambertville, NJ, we observed and commented on the smaller sign suspended beneath the painted wooden restaurant scripted plank.

"Falafel."

The dining room was heavily atmospheric, with exposed red brick, hanging metal/glass lights, and attractive Middle Eastern wall art. The small candles in colorful glass holders added to the flickering ambiance. 

We ordered the falafel/hummus combo plate based on their advertisement outside, and the chicken shawarma platter. Both large plates arrived about 15 minutes later. A hot pillowy pita came along for the ride. 

Needless to say we were disappointed when we attempted to pick up a falafel ball with a fork. The surface was impenetrable and the tines bounced off as if striking a rock. Plan B was picking the sphere up with my fingers and locking down with my bicuspids. My jaw forced the hard shell to collapse, only to find that the ground chickpeas within were chokingly dry and almost tasteless. A hard case disaster. 

Made us wonder who was doing quality control in the kitchen? Why would the chef, manager or server who saw what was being served allow them to reach our table? These hardballs should have been trashed. But, it was actually worse than that. 

The kitchen lacked vertical rotisserie grills for the proper preparation of gyros and shawarmas. Thus, the chicken which should have been sliced thin and constantly basted in a complex marinade was instead cut in small chunks and heated on hot steel. It was also far too dry and poorly spiced. If there was a marinade, it was weak or had only a passing acquaintance with the chicken. It was dry, lifeless and barely edible. O for 2.

On the other hand, the hummus was excellent and eating it with torn pieces of pita, great finger food. A wise person once said that life is short; eat dessert first. The baklava at Marhaba was unbelievably wonderful. Baked in-house, the phylo, honey and pistachio concoction was about the best I'd ever eaten. If that had been all we tried, this would have been a 5 star review, and we would have been very happy campers. 

We only wish that we had followed that sage advice. It would have saved us time, money, dissatisfaction and many questions.

Dessert Review

We stopped in Adonio's Diner as the last stop after foot massage and Afghani dinner. Just wanted some java and something sweet to finish the night's run. They advertise that they had a bakery, so they had to have some nice stuff. Right?

Not quite. 

Perhaps, because it was a long holiday weekend, and they gave the Baker's the day off, but all they had was cheesecake and apple crumb pie, neither of which looked to be made in house.  Ordered the apple slice anyway. I have never seen a smaller excuse for a diner dessert. Where most diners go out of their way to be excessive in these situations, Adonio's fit on a small saucer, practically flat and with little apple.The taste was industrial. The accompanying cuppa joe was also small and not very good.

The dinner customers were scoring large platters of whatever, and seemed satisfied. So, this was all about apres diner offerings. For unknown reasons, mine sucked. My friend's rice pudding was okay, but also miniscule compared to what most diners provide. 

First and last impression.

This Wendy's is freestanding in the parking lot of the shopping plaza that also contains Maryanne's Homestyle Restaurant.  It has not been completely modernized yet, but it is basically clean and ready for the effort Dave Thomas' ghost is making to upgrade their facilities. They do have that super soda dispenser that allows the customer to pour their own from a multitude of options.  

We ordered the basic Dave's Single and Double, French Fries, and a drink.  Not bad, but both of our burgers were only slightly above room temperature.  They had obviously been cooked at some time before serving, and taken from a warming drawer to make the sandwich without a thought to reheating, or even putting the patty back on the grill for a couple of minutes before laying on the cold lettuce, tomato, cheese and onion.  Thus, while the veggies were cool and fresh, the main attraction suffered greatly by comparison, as the meat needed more heat to make it a full player.  

Edible, but why couldn't they check on the patty and serve it at optimal temperature?  

The soda machine was fun, though.

We probably should have gone to Maryanne's.

Once upon a time, Vince's Pizza in Yardley was a regular stop on the underground pizza railway running from Bristol up to Riegelsville. 

It seems that somewhere along the way Vince's recipe or his touch for making good tomato pie got lost.  Today, my slices were doughy rather than crisp, not well reheated in the oven, and had a slightly bitter taste.  Too, it failed the most crucial pizza test - when lifted off the paper plate the point sagged like an old dog ear and immediately began to drip oil.  This was not the experience I was anticipating when I stopped in to renew acquaintances with one of my old haunts.  

The price for the slices and small drink was just slightly above 5 bucks, which was great, but I would have gladly paid more for quality pizza. 

Oh, woe is me.  How the mighty have fallen.

For the sake of comparison, I decided to visit the Giant Supermarket in the Flowers Mill Shopping Center, Langhorne, Pa., just to see how it stacked up against my local market in Newtown/Middletown.  

Not very well, I'm afraid. 

While as large or larger than my local Giant, the layout was inferior, and the space felt dark from poor lighting.  It was difficult to find certain items that were not where they logically belonged (i.e., Bubba Burgers). So, I found myself wandering down aisles thinking that there was something wrong with my vision.  No. It wasn't me.  

Service was fine, and the cashier very friendly.  

Still, my neighborhood store retains my loyalty.

(We) Miss Philly Grill is a stainless steel façade food emporium on Philmont Avenue in Huntingdon Valley, Montgomery County, PA.  If first impressions are important, this joint needs some help because the parking lot is a minefield of potholes to be avoided before even considering walking inside.  Not worth a tire or rim just to check out their breakfast, but if you are careful, you can make it without damaging your wheels. 

Once inside, the décor and ambiance take you to another time and place somewhere in South Philadelphia in the middle of the last century. The walls are hung with Marilyn, James Dean, Connie Mack Stadium, etc., and the upholstery of the booths is red and white leatherette. Attractive and gitchy. Most of the patrons appear to be regulars from the first-naming going on with the staff. Almost all of them were bilingual and seemed interested in attending to everyone's needs.  The breakfast menu was extensive, with many specials and combo plates for those desiring a thimble of juice and mug of Joe with their egg dishes.  I certainly did.

I went with the french toast, orange juice and java. In reverse order, the coffee was decent, but served with those coffee creamer things. As that is all corn syrup and chemicals, I requested some milk as an alternative. I got it, but it took a while. The main course was okay, but it was presented sloppily, looking like the cook had just tossed it on the plate with no attempt to make it look attractive.  There were even little pieces of eggy bread detached from the slices on the dish.  I had to reorganize it before putting on the butter and syrup.  The "butter" was all prepackaged in tiny plastic tubs, and had the consistency of soft margarine.  Syrup? It came out of a label-less plastic squeeze bottle that had been refilled a million time with an industrial strength amber sweet goo. The OJ was poured from a large plastic pitcher of unknown age and origin. 

You get the picture. 

Every corner that could be cut to save a penny, was sliced thin. The result was a breakfast that could not be traced to the source, nor offered with pride of ownership. It wasn't that it was a bad meal, it's just that it lacked care and quality control.  The taste was close to being good, but fell short in various ways.

Miss Philly Grill? It takes more than a chill environment to make me miss it enough to want a return visit with all the potholes inside and out.

There are dive bars.  There are dumpy dive bars.  And, then there are hell holes.  

Penn Tavern sits at the borderline between the last two, as well as on a dark strip of West Bridge Street in Morrisville, Pa.  The evening I was there the crowd was sparse with no more than 6 people on stools around the worn out bar.  The friendly/attractive bartender was just back from surgery and was obviously uncomfortable moving around.  The folks on one side of me were in a conversation laced with F-bombs.  The person on the other side was singing along with the music coming from the jukebox in the basement (I was amazed she could hear it).  

The floor was in need of reinforcement, as only the underflooring was visible behind the bar.  The draft beer handles were all off to one side at the edge of the bar zone, attached to the freezer where the kegs were housed.  It had been a very long time since I saw a set up like that. All the pulls looked to be domestic.  My Yuengling mug was only $2, and I read elsewhere that a $.75 draft was available.  

I needed a place to spend an hour while waiting for a local class to let out, and Penn Tavern was the next on the list for a visit.  Compared to the other neighborhood drinking halls, this is at the bottom of the (beer) barrel.

MUFFIN & COFFEE BREAKFAST REVIEW ONLY

Stopped in the Vincentown Diner after court in Mt. Holly this morning for a late light breakfast. It has been at least a decade since my last visit, and aside from the new sign out front, the inside looked basically the same with two main dining areas, a long counter with spinners, and servers in black.  It also has signs referring to local sourced foods, craft beer, and french press coffee.  The lighting seemed a bit dim which felt more somber than comforting. 

I sat at the counter and was promptly approached by a woman in black offering a menu and asking if I wanted something to drink.  Coffee, please.  It arrived in a larger cup, about twice the size of the normal diner serving.  Nice touch. Felt generous. 

I inquired about muffins, and was advised they had corn and blueberry.  A toasted corn muffin was exactly what I wanted.  The menu called them, "The Real Deal!"  It arrived cut in thirds and well grilled on top and bottom.  I small cup of butter and two jelly containers came along for the ride. I spread some butter on the heated surfaces, but pushed the sweets aside.  

First bite was a small surprise.  Rather than having that expected corn muffin flavor, the mix included Lemon Zest, making the taste more a lemon corn muffin, than the traditional rich corn flavor and texture.  Disappointing, but certainly an acceptable variant if notified beforehand.  That was not the case here.  

All the above would have resulted in a three star review, but for the heartburn I have been suffering since leaving the diner.  Whether the coffee or the muffin were the "Real Deal," or not, that was an aftertaste I could live without.

While Peace Valley Park is a beautiful oasis of field, forest and water, when I visited last weekend there was nary a parking space. People were packed in on the trails and along the waterfront with little concern for social distancing, nor masks. It looked so unsafe to be there despite the perfect weather, that we decided not to search for parking, but to leave the park for another less overcrowded day. 

We are all feeling rammy about the too long quarantine and have chronic cabin fever, but to ignore the advice of health experts that precautions remain essential to avoid infection, is to not only risk my own life, but the lives of those I love. 

The North Branch of Neshaminy Creek and the reservoir from its damming (Lake Galena) will still be there when it is safer to explore.

These new fangled Wawa stores are a great improvement over the last generation small box iteration with too small parking areas, and limited prepared food options. The 21st Century variation are at least 2,500 square feet, with gas pumps outside and elaborate food kitchen and computer aided ordering system able to please even the most picky pallette. The coffee hasn't changed much, but then again, it was darn good back in the day, and remains so. 

But, despite the impressive modernization, these roadside way stations are far from perfect, and actually create some problems that didn't exist before. This facility on Parkway Avenue in Ewing, NJ, offers obvious examples of this evolution. 

Access is only through a side street and a too narrow long driveway off to the side in front. At a significant intersection, it makes for challenging traffic entering from Parkway or exiting from the rear of the property. Too, there isn't enough parking around the building to accommodate all the folks going inside for food and drink. Two things therefore happen; first, people are encouraged to leave their vehicles at the gas pumps while they shop within, and second, others park illegally wherever they can, hoping not to cause a park rage incident. I've seen one such confrontation, and it wasn't pretty. 

This friction point is exacerbated within by understaffed kitchen help causing back up in food prep and lots of people milling about with receipts waiting for their numbers to be called. It's a beautiful industrial kitchen, but whenever I am there, several food stations are without preparers, while one or two areas over backed up to the max. So, people wait, while many cars are interfering with traffic flow outside, and people can't get gasoline because abandoned looking vehicles clog the gas islands.

Bottom line, the store is too big for the lot it occupies, leaving too few parking spots. Greedy developers clearly oversold their prowess as designers of business flow, and the undermanned planning commissions approved the plan without adequate analysis. The internals should work, but if management fails to adapt to reality, there will never be enough workers on site to handle the crush inhouse caused by poor planning on the outside and shift manpower shortages. 

This is how old problems reemerge in the new world. Poor planning and management is timeless, and in some cases, inevitable.

PS. The chicken salad on wheat torpedo was quite good.

Found a nail embedded in the edge of the tread in a Run Flat Michelin. Drove over to Mavis on Route 1 across from Oxford Valley Mall because I had had a good experience at a different one of their tire havens in Richboro, PA. This one was closer to home. 

The place was moderately busy with four bays with cars in varying degrees of repair or tire changes. Good sign I thought. Walking in, a manager approached to ask if I had an appointment. Didn't know I needed one, but he was cool about it. A few minutes later we went to look at my tire problem, saw the nail sticking out, advised me it had to be replaced due to where it was, and returned to the front desk to see if it was in stock. 

It wasn't. But, he would order it and have it by Saturday sometime. He said he would call me when it came in and we would switch out the bad for the new. Sounded like a reasonable plan. I left there satisfied. What was one day?

The call never came and I ended up visiting a different tire center that also had to call for the Run Flat to be delivered to them the same day, for a few bucks less. They did call on arrival and the swap out was accomplished later the same afternoon. 

Really appreciated their effort and friendly professionalism, even if their name wasn't Mavis.

This review reflects only the lunch buffet and service surrounding it. 

In a sequence of odd/violative behavior from the moment we walked in:

 ~ Although the place was almost empty, the greeter walked us to a booth right next to the only other occupants of the restaurant.  We relocated ourselves so all of us could have some privacy, but new customers were continually brought to the same area and seated too close to each other. The remainder of the floor remained unoccupied. I realize this is a Chinese custom, but here it is not cool.  VIOLATION.

~ The buffet looks great, yet although we were making our choices shortly after 12, everything placed on my plate was at best warm, and at worst, room temperature. Nothing I tried was heated to the right temperature range. VIOLATION

~ One of the managers came out of the kitchen to check what was needed. She was not dressed for kitchen work, nor did she wear gloves as she handled the food and utensils, pushing the contents of the chaffing dishes around to make room for more.  VIOLATION

~ As we were eating our first round of food, and long before we were finished, a wait person dropped off the bill in the plastic billfold.  Not only was it "served" way too early, but it was placed right next to our plates full of food.  The table was otherwise empty, and there was plenty of space for it to be laid an appropriate distance from our plates. Not a word was said, and the male server seemed almost hostile.  We relocated it to the opposite corner of the table away from us.  VIOLATION

 I hesitate to consider what goes on with the sushi. 

No seconds today, thanks.
